column4:
Just as Priest had presumed, Deegan had to depart Smotherland via the narrow stairway exiting the club.  But, he was smart.  Or, just damned lucky.  He exited in a crowd.  Not that he was associating with any of them, his eyes were distant as if in thought.  He was distracted.  Distraction worked for Priest as it would make his job much easier.

Priest, roll +Hard to Make your move. On a 10+, describe what happened; how you caught/killed Deegan and retrieved Omak’s wife’s necklace.  Describe the necklace.  

On a 7-9, choose 2 of the following:  You catch/kill Deegan but he does not have the necklace (describe the encounter); Deegan manages to get away, but you retrieve the necklace (describe the encounter); You are not observed or identified (i.e. you get away clean).  

On a 6 or less, you fail to catch Deegan or retrieve the necklace.  Some complication befalls you, what is it?

SESSION END: No actions or changes.  (He was active for too short a time to get to know anyone or make any Hx changes.)

column3: Jump to last post

column1: <div id=""messages-region"" class=""roleplay-messages span_12""><div><div class=""message-list""><div class=""message"" id=""message-322932""><div class=""row"">

Priest followed Deegan for a mile or so, through cramped alleys, over two half-demolished walls, and through an open-air food stall (fresh corgies).

Priest had a hunch he should wait, but wasn't sure why. When he nearly lost Deegan as he skirted Uncle Lin's place, Priest moved on him. It was pathetically easy: Priest rushed Deegan, Deegan panicked and fell.

So there they were. Priest laid his katana's blade to Deegan's neck and asked him some easy questions.

Deegan made a mess of the answers. ""I don't have the necklace. I left it with some guy at the club. No, not sold it. Loaned it, like proof, so I could get it back later. His name was Fek Bols. Fek deals in rare birds and promised to hold the necklace until I could get the jingle. Well, I owe Sully jingle for some boots I stole from this bruiser over at the west side. His sister needed some meds for her headache and because her mother knew my cousin...""

To make it easier, Priest lied and told Deegan he'd live. So Deegan got up slowly and relaxed. That's when Priest decapitated him. He searched the body to make sure about the necklace. It was missing. He took the small amount of jingle that was present for bribes and Deegan's jacket (for proof of death).

Priest cleaned his blade and walked off to find a place to sleep for the night. He would continue the search for the necklace tomorrow. The necklace was described by Omak as a misshapen heart. Its value was in the material, perhaps?

(This is what it actually looks like - Priest hasn't seen it)
dice roll

Questions prior to Session 3 Start: 

Where does Priest stay during the night?  Or, during the duration of his hunt for the necklace?

Does he have any local connections?  If not any of the established PCs/NPCs, then who?

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Questions prior to Session 3 Start: </p><p style=""margin-left: 20px;"">Where does Priest stay during the night?  Or, during the duration of his hunt for the necklace?</p><p style=""margin-left: 20px;"">Does he have any local connections?  If not any of the established PCs/NPCs, then who?</p>

Three nights ago Priest found a slagged and half-collapsed apartment building in Bell Town on the border with Denny. He knows he should sleep above the ground floor, but is concerned about being trapped. This is home base at the moment. He sleeps in a slanted, ground floor apartment (used to be second floor).

Priest has very few established connections in Bell Town because he came here to escape his past. In/near Bell Town, Priest knows:
• Sisqo -- from the old days, but doesn't know Sisqo is in/near Bell Town.
• Uncle Lin -- spent some time at his hold. Priest may go there and ask for some help.

<li>Uncle Lin -- spent some time at his hold. Priest may go there and ask for some help.</li>

column4:
Uncle Lin’s plans to seek what treasure (or, might it be more properly consider plunder?) had to be set on hold for a bit.  These bold adventurer types seemed to be far more interested in some pressing personal matters than conducting business.  Their injured and dying friend, and the child, seemed to be a distraction for them.  No matter, the “treasure” would (probably) keep.

Dee Dee did, indeed, seem to be the sister of the injured woman named Dana.  From what he can gather from his people attending to the wounded woman, and what he has gleaned from Dee Dee, they worked as a team exploring the old city of Seattle.  Dee Dee is an almost encyclopedia of the city and was rumored to have friends or acquaintances just about everywhere.  

Dana, on the other hand, worked as a mercenary of a sort.  More of a bounty hunter, if the snippets of conversation that had been reported to him might be true.  Somehow, she had been tasked with returning this little girl, Hope, to Zayden and Thor, and those two thugs had likewise spread the word that the girl was worth a fine bounty and that she was their kin.  Such sentimentality did not track for Zayden, and Uncle Lin would not think that he would pay any amount of jingle for Thor should THAT dimbulb be lost to him.

So, Uncle Lin’s plans are on hold for a bit.  But, he is confident that he can move ahead on them soon enough.

[The “treasure” is on board a ship that is grounded, half sunk, or otherwise trapped up the coast a bit.  What does this rumored “treasure” consist of?  What kind of ship is it?  Why might it be secure for the time being?  What difficulties might hinder scavengers (monsters, dangers, bad guys, etc.)?]

It's an old cargo ship, and it holds tech that would allow for the building of environment control devices. Good enough to clean up the garage the Clan lives in, and (maybe?) even good enough to push back the Growth outside of town. It's secure because there's rumours of a cannibal gang around the area, and maybe something that lives in the water? 

Anyway, nobody who goes after the ship has come back

END OF SESSION 2:

At the end of every session, choose a character who knows you better than they used to. If there’s more than one, choose one at your whim. Tell that player to add +1 to their Hx with you on their sheet. If this brings them to Hx+4, they reset to Hx+1 (and therefore mark experience). 

If no one knows you better, choose a character who doesn’t know you as well as they thought, or choose any character at your whim. Tell that player to take -1 to their Hx with you on their sheet. If this brings them to Hx -3, they reset to Hx=0 (and therefore mark experience).

(I'll leave this to you, as your interaction with other PCs was so short, that it may not be practical to assume that any of them got to know you any better or worse.)

column1: <div id=""messages-region"" class=""roleplay-messages span_12""><div><div class=""message-list""><div class=""message"" id=""message-322971""><div class=""row"">

3rd day of Otenir, GR 1232 (5145 KS); Outskirts of Ghanda's Grave

""Fuck your whore of a grandmother!"" Aleshkina growled as his foot sank half way up the calf into a patch of sucking mud concealed by the shallow layer of brackish grey-brown that seemed to cover everything in this cursed place. The fleshy crimson blossoms - the only patch of colour in a pale monochromatic morass - seemed almost to taunt him with their leonine faces. Were they all turned to him? No, surely that was mere fancy.

The young Vicighan lordling was more aware than he had ever been. More present in the moment. Bereft of his retinue he was, for the first time he could recall, completely under his own protection and the prospect that had thrilled him in the warm halls of his father's manse seemed dreadful now that it was reality. His guards and his valets awaited on the fringe of this storied stretch of misty marshland, no doubt with dry kimono and warm wine. What was he thinking? Did men truly stray into this too-still bog hard by the bones of a fallen Divhi? Was the witch worth such trouble.

The young nobleman smoothed his oiled brows, which swept in a perfect arc down his pale cheeks and back along his jutting jaw with hands that were somehow sweating despite the airless chill of late Autumn. He regretted his hunting silks - they did nothing save cover his nakedness now that they were wet with the fog and filthy with mud.

Where in the name of all the spirits was the place Marushka had described? He felt... observed somehow.

He regretted his hunting silks - they did nothing save cover his nakedness now that they were wet with the fog and filthy with mud.</p><p>Where in the name of all the spirits was the place Marushka had described? He felt... <em>observed </em>somehow.<em><br></em></p>

Handsome. Clumsy and haughty, sure, but handsome still.

Barely hidden behind a curtain of dried reeds, her bare feet immersed in the fresh water, Srebrenka smiled as she observed the young man crawl and rant his way through the marsh. 

Granted, she could have chosen a place of easier access : but he had not earned enough of her trust for her to directly invite him in her small hut, let alone the small subterannean chamber in which her, her mother, the mother of her mother and every women in her line had practiced the Art since centuries.

Her eyes traveled, detailing the damp clothes adhering to the stranger's defined muscles. Clearly, this wasn’t one of the townsfolk – in fact, given the expensiveness of the fabrics he wore, not a commoner at all. She never held noble clients in her heart - too much gall and haggling, all meant to hide their uneasiness towards a power and legacy other than theirs. 

But that one seemed different. Marushka, the young seer that she used as her spokesperson in Dmansi, had told her so two months ago, when she came bearing the lordling's plight. And indeed : not only had the guy waited the mandatory delay until the Crescent Moon, but he did agree to come here, unescorted, to the utmost edge of civilization, instead of sending a servant fetch the command he surely was about to make. This revealed a dedication rarely displayed by her wealthier clientele: rare enough to pique her curiosity, at least.

As he passed her by, cursing, she crept behind him, her experienced feet finding the emerged spots as from their own accord, barely leaving a ripple upon the stale water.

“I’d advise against the use of such words towards elders in a witch's domain, fair prince,” she softly said, grazing the aristocrat’s shoulders in a way that made her hand look like a large, fleshy spider.  “My grandmother is dead since sixteen moons, but – who knows? She might be tempted to take you at your word.” Her grin widened, parting to reveal two rows of immaculate teeth, glistening like pearls… or gnawed-clean bones.
dice roll

dice roll
The sodden lordling let out an inarticulate yelp as Srebrenka spoke,
launching himself forward and falling prone on the boggy ground briefly
submerging his face in the filthy ground water and marring his silks yet
further beyond repair. When he spun to face her the witch saw that he
was not so handsome any more, his drooping brows plastered into his
hair, which now sported a snarl of twigs. His face was ghost pale
beneath an oozing mask or sodden earth. His clinging silks revealed a

generous girth cleverly hidden by tailors.

Staring wide eyed he demanded, in a tremulous and suddenly pitchy voice ""Who are you? Are you the witch of the Grave that they speak of?""

Srebrenka could see short thumb-sized grey bodies emerging from the marsh around his hands. Leeches and grubs might well be on their way to investigate the tumult in their waters, but it was the strange and misshapen sorrow elementals that seemed ever-present in this place that came first to gather around the fallen man. They would drive him into a bleak depression if he sat amongst them too long, and then that might draw the antlered giant known only as The Strider that haunted this land. Srebrenka had seen its silhouette passing between the willows once when the blue moon waned and something at the core of her very soul never wanted to have cause encounter the thing again.

One lidless saucer eye in pastels of red and yellow and blue that spoke only of misery and sadness emerged at the end of one of the fleshy bodies to stare at the lordling.
dice roll

smile at the man’s ridiculous question – who could she be, dressed like that in
the middle of the marsh? A damsel in distress? – soon dropped as she started to
notice the congregation of spirits. That wasn’t good. She wasn’t nearly
powerful enough to hope to survive to the Strider’s onslaught, let alone to also

protect her whining swine of a client.

She threw a mocking

glance to the fallen noble, before raising a finger to her lips in a shushing gesture. There. This way, he wouldn't start fussing about the elementals. Not if he knew what was good for him, at least.

Arboring her nicest
smile, and focusing her mind on a few of her happiest memories, Srebrenka
leaned herself down, holding out a welcoming hand to the tiny crowd of ephemeral
one is not for you, my pretties. I doubt his sadness runs quite deep enough
to feed you. He will pay the price for having disturbed your slumber, rest

assured... But not now. Not here. That would probably get our dear, deer-faced Strider to pay us a visit, and I really wouldn't like that...”

The words weren’t
really important – she wasn’t even sure that the elementals used any form of language between themselves.
However, as beings of pure emotions, she knew them to be able to discern
meaning through more instinctive ways, infering her emotions and intentions from
the slightest change in the inflexions of her voice or the expressions of her

face. At least, she had to hope so.

Firmly, she held the
gaze of the one that first opened her eyes. The pastel pupils engulfed her, and the usual wave of melancholia briefly submerged her. Images started to form in
the back of her head – her mother, her ancestors, and even her divh, all dead
and gone under the liquid grave of the lake. Her eyes watered, and her hand slighty
shook, but she stoically kept it held out towards the elemental – open, unarmed and

waiting.

 “You, little one. Come with me. We’ll go
somewhere calmer. You’ll speak for your brethren. You’ll show me what they require to make up for this trespasser's offence.

somewhere calmer. You’ll speak for your brethren. You’ll show me what they require to make up for this trespasser's offence.

At a taste of joy the fat little creatures melted back into the aether from whence they had come, not repelled no rebuked so much as disinterested. After all, there was sorrow aplenty in this place and if it were merely the lordling's fear that drew them to congregate then they would certainly be better served gathering about some wailing pilgrim or weeping mystic. Only the creature mere inches from her finger - the first to stare out of the other world - remained.

It fixed Srebrenka with a stare from its massive eye and lolled its plump white bulk to the side in a motion that might almost be quizzical. No, if the elementals were slivers of the fractured soul of the land then these were no more intelligent nor desirous than goosebumps that rise unbidden at the gentle touch of the morning air, and the prone lordling no more than that air.

Even as she thought it the elemental regarding Srebrenka made a lazy roll that seemed to fold its dimensions in on themselves until it turned a flank to her that seemed infinitely thin, and then it was gone leaving her with only the faint melancholy that was as much a part of this place as tree or water.

The young man scrambled to his feet, embarrassment fighting a battle with outrage in his dark eyes. He looked Srebrenka over warily as she reached out to the elemental, more wary of the witch than the spirit. Like as not he thought these creatures no less base than the spark elementals that gathered on the hearth or the storm ghosts that emerged when the skies darkened, or the tree sprites that showed themselves on the warmest of spring nights. And perhaps the sorrow elementals were the same, but they demanded a caution that those others did not.

""You are the witch."" he proclaimed, wonder creeping into his voice. Had he believed her mythical? It seemed every other town in Vo Chor had a wise woman living on its outskirts who was spoken of with a mix of reverence and disdain. Was she so different?

Had he believed her mythical? It seemed every other town in Vo Chor had a wise woman living on its outskirts who was spoken of with a mix of reverence and disdain. Was she so different?</p>

Srebrenka sighed, as the ephemeral being she tried to beckon faded into the airs. The phenomenon wasn't a total surprise - she witnessed it more than once - but each time, she couldn't help but speaking to the small impish beings as if they were more than mirages, with the foolish hope that one of them would engage some form of exchange, lift some segment of the veil of secrecy that shrouded the Shadow World and its denizens. She should have known better. Sentimentalism, she scolded herself, was of no help in these lands.

""I am"" she answered Aleshkina, softly, but a little more abruptly than before. ""That said, I don’t quite understand why you say it like it was some kind
where you're from?"" She frowned suddenly, thinking of something.""And where in the duchy do you come from, anyways? Marushka failed to tell me.""

where you're from?</span></strong><b style=""background-color: initial;"">"" </b>She frowned suddenly, thinking of something.<b style=""background-color: initial;"">""And <em>where</em> in the duchy do you come from, anyways? Marushka failed to tell me.""</b></p>

The newcomer puffed out his chest and jutted his chin in a parchment-thin veneer of courage. ""I am Aleshkina Bravatz, second son to the Zupan of Sukvani. We have our women of lore but Marushka promised me that only you who dwell upon the fringes of the Grave know the lore I seek."" He looked about, uncertain at what the mist concealed. Even Srebrenka had to allow that his watchfulness was prudent.

Srebrenka considered for a moment - Sukvani was not a place she had much cause to venture to. A couple of small hamlets gathered around a modest palace perhaps a half-day ride distant. There was little to distinguish it from a dozen other noblemen's demesnes like it. And a second son no less! So this Aleshkina was of little import then. Still, he must live a life of such luxury and privilege as she doubted she could even dream. It must be an errand of no small import that drew him from the pleasures of nightly masques, gluttonous feasts and debauched festivities.

Why had Marushka the huntsman sent this soft-handed fop into her range? Mere coin no doubt, but he might still prove as amusing as he was lucrative.

""Hmph."" Srebrenka turned her eyes away from Aleshkina, visibly displeased. She always hated second sons, as customers. They had the same level of ambition than a firstborn, but never learned to rein it in or hide it like a last-in-line heir would have. 

She started to walk further from the brackish puddle in which the young noble had fell, treading the dry path from whence she had observed the young noble. Without even glancing at him, she briskly gestured towards Aleshkina, indicating him to follow her. ""Well, there's no point in delaying if you came from that far. Make your pitch and name your price, dukeling. And for Ghanda's sake, do so quickly.""

Make your pitch and name your price, dukeling. And for Ghanda's sake, do so <em>quickly</em>.""</strong></p>

Srebrenka could almost feel the youngster's eyes bulge at her impertinence. In another land she imagined a lordling might have her flogged, even killed, but the Ghans were not so stiff as the Ralstaans or Haedrasians and did not take the authority of those of fortunate birth quite so seriously. But then perhaps he was a reasonable lad, and this was mere fancy.

""I-"" Aleshkina began, faltering as he dragged himself from the mire ""I have come on behalf of my... friend. He is ill and I fear for him. And also..."" he lowered his voice sheepishly ""Also I fear that I might share in his malady."" Srebrenka could hear the boy's feet crunch onto the path behind her. ""I know you are no healer by trade"" he added hurriedly, anticipating her retort ""But you know this place like few others, and you recall its perils in a way the mystics cannot, and he came back from a pilgrimage to the Grave... changed. I had hoped that perhaps your herb lore..."" He left the thought hanging - like as not because he had no words for exactly what he expected her to do.

Nothing was proof against the witch's probing examination and even a glance told her much about her indiscreet visitor. He seemed hale save for the tribulations the swamp had visited upon him, but then the most insidious of  illness could linger without sign for days, even months before striking. Still, it seemed evident that this was his first journey into the grave, and so if his friend became ill here... perhaps a venom or poison rather than an ailment?

Aleshkina was still disconcerted by his surroundings and by
Srebrenka's seeming mastery of terrain that had so entrapped him, and it
seemed he was less cautious with his words than he might be at court in
his father's hall or his Ban's palace. ""Manushka is a retainer, nothing
more!"" he lied after an obvious moment of consideration ""But a valuable

one, and I will not brook the loss of something of value unopposed.""

""He
sought guidance, to commune with Ghanda on some trivial matter."" not a
lie this time by the slackening of his shoulder, but the flitting eyes

suggested something held back ""When he returned his skin was pale, and as the days since have passed he has begun to sweat, and to be gripped by the most horrifying terrors when he sleeps. Of late he speaks sometimes in a voice unlike his own and make reference to things that the physicians of my father's court cannot decipher. And then..."" he trailed off, eyes flicking directly to Srebreka for the first time since he began speaking before darting away ""In any case, it was to the sleeper shrine to the north that he went, and none of the mystics there have the sense in them anymore to even say whether he reached the shrine or not in the three days he was gone.""

It skulks behind the windows, looking out, taking in. It knows where the knife is. It understands the perilous, wet softness of mortality. It has died a dozen times over in flesh. Flesh is weak, but expedient. Expedient for one who sheds flesh as a coat.

The witch is strong. Noble. She knows the art. And yet there is something.

""Please. I worry that we will be too late."" it lets the vestige of a man rasp through its horrid meat-flaps, the sentiment only half heeded by the terrible passenger.

The witch turns to lead the way and It surges forward. Finds the knife. It spends the body in which is hides, heedless that now the meat flaps are screaming. Crying. Blubbering in agony. Choking on their own insides as they surge outward.

The arms uncoil as it takes command of them, but this only whips the knife into the witch more swiftly. The eyes turn black.

There is blood. Blood from both.

The unravelled ruin of Aleshkina sits atop the witch, striking again and again until long after the man within has fled the pain of his own unmaking. It stabs until the arms so unravel that they are useless tendrils sinuous ruin. It tears with It's teeth until they are all dislodged in the gore that is two inexorably made one.

Then It is gone. It has others to find, and only eternity to do it in.

Srebrenka heard a gurgling noise from behind her as she led the way, which turned into a whine. She began to turn and then there was a pain in her back.

Then the pain grew.

The mercy of death came slowly to the seeress of the Dead Divh's Grave. What little mercy Fate had for her saw her fall face down, so as not to see the horror her assailant became.

column4: Sorority Spring Break Slasher Flick: Direct to Video Campaign

It’s a gorgeous, sunny early afternoon on Isla Caliente, and the Spring Break partiers are almost all pretty well buzzed already. Driving club music plays loudly over the speakers at Party Center Stage on the gleaming white beach. Some inflatable pools have been set up on the stage and filled a couple of inches deep with coconut-scented baby oil. The DJ announces a bikini oil wrestling contest with free booze for a day as the prize.

ASPECTS:

Bikinis, Booze, and Bad Decisions

An Unsuspected Threat

Nudity (25 free invocations)

Violation (10 free invocations—invocations grant a +3 bonus, and may only be used once per scene)

Each PC should answer the following questions:
• What risqué behavior have you just been engaging in that you wouldn’t normally if you weren’t drinking, and what evidence can we see of your lack of self-control?
• Whose attention would you most like to get right now?
<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Each PC should answer the following questions:</p><ul>
<li>What risqué behavior have you just been engaging in that you wouldn’t normally if you weren’t drinking, and what evidence can we see of your lack of self-control?</li>
<li>Whose attention would you most like to get right now?</li>

It had started innocent enough with a few drinks among friends. Then, somehow it turned into Truth or Dare.

""Who on this island would you like to make out with?"" Rico questioned Destiny.

""Rico! I chose DARE!"" She corrected him.

""OK. I dare you to go the entire afternoon topless."" He shot back with a lurid grin.

""Well, I dare you to go the entire afternoon without a camera."" Destiny challenged Rico, who had invited himself to the party.

Justin looked at both of them.

""Fine."" She blurted out and took off the top of her black bikini and tossed it across Justin's shoulder.

""Fine."" Rico's eyes widened and he handed over all his video and camera devices to Justin.

""If this gets out because of you, I'll kill you."" Destiny warned him, with a gesture toward her own naked torso.

""Oh yeah! And if you don't stay topless until 5 pm, you'll pose nude for me.""

""Fine!""

""Fine!""

Hearing the roar of the gathering crowd for the oil wrestling, Destiny took Justin's arm and headed out of the private cabana sans top.

Jay walked out and onto the beach hand in hand with Rachel, under a large purple parasol adorned with a single white star covering it. One moment they were having a few drinks with friends and the next a session of Truth or Dare was under way. At the moment she couldn't remember who had started it. She and Rachel didn't normally display more than hand holding and light kisses in front of others or in public, but relaxed with friends and drink, they had been openly making out while they both plied enough sunscreen to keep Rachel's pale skin from igniting into flames once they hit the beach. 

Jay is horny as hell as they approach the area of the stage. There's no denying the give of her super hard nipples pressing against the tight fabric of her bikini top. She wanted to keep Rachel's attention. Hell, she wanted more than just her attention right now. But, damn! Look at all the fine ass co-eds on the beach.

'This could be heaven or this could be hell...' She thought to herself.

""Don't tickle or it's going to spill!"" Mimi was bent backwards across Emilio's lap as he lay sprawled out on the lounge. Her head hung off of one side and her butt hung off the other. She squatted down, her feet braced on the beach blanket. The douche frat boy carefully poured Cuervo into her navel, and she held her breath. She tried to remember his name, but there were so many of them. He leaned over her, and pressed his lips to her belly, and slurped.

She let out a squeal and sat up so abruptly she nearly knocked him over. She fell forward onto her knees, laughing, and looked back at Emilio, whose only comment was a long, slow snore.

""Yo, your dude's out,"" another one of the frat brothers called out. ""Come hang with us, yo.""

Mimi bit her lip, torn. The guy was right. Emilio was passed out. These guys were fun. More fun than her sleeping stud. On the other hand, she had a good thing going with him. Did she want to risk blowing it to drink shitty tequila with these dudebros? She poked him, but he kept snoring.   

Just then she heard the DJ come on the sound system. 

""Oil wrestling?"" she said, her eyes lighting up. She looked at Emilio. What he didn't know, she thought to herself. She'd be back before he got a sunburn. She stood up, straightening her skimpy bikini, and headed over to the wrestling area

She poked him, but he kept snoring.   </p><p>Just then she heard the DJ come on the sound system. </p><p><strong>""Oil wrestling?""</strong> she said, her eyes lighting up. She looked at Emilio. What he didn't know, she thought to herself. She'd be back before he got a sunburn. She stood up, straightening her skimpy bikini, and headed over to the wrestling area</p>

Callie can’t believe the stuff people are willing to do in this truth or dare game. This crowd is way more raucous than she would normally be comfortable with, but the rum-based cocktail she’s been nursing has taken the edge off her social anxiety. Those girls making out in the corner seem more into it than merely putting on a show for the guys...OHMYGOD, THAT OTHER CHICK JUST TOOK HER TOP OFF! Callie blushes like she’s the one with her bare tits on display and involuntarily glances over at Ben.

His eyes are fixed on the topless girl’s nipples, but almost as if he senses Callie’s glance he returns her look and their eyes meet. Then Ben’s eyes drop to Callie’s bust for a split second before returning to meet her gaze, grinning. Callie blushes again and tugs her bikini top up unnecessarily, discomfited by Ben’s attention to her chest. The next moment he goes back to ogling the pair of breasts less confined by modesty.

Dammit, Callie! How are you going to get with a hunk like Ben If you’re so buttoned-up all the time? He never even noticed you before your  total makeover, and now you’re going back to your old mousey persona! Cut loose a little!

Callie hears the announcement of the oil wrestling contest, and the approving whoops of various male partiers.

Oh God, get me out of here!

column4:
A reunião acontece, e são apresentados para duas pessoas pelos irmãos Torna-sol. Mileto, um garoto gentil e as vezes bem reservado, e Aurora, uma maga de um mal humor bem grande, e bem suspeita das coisas. Com Mileto as coisas são bem mais tranquilas que com Aurora, que sai da sala após ter suas perguntas não respondidas.
Alias, ao que parece, entrar na faculdade quando uma festa acontece, é praticamente impossível, e deixa ambos os 4 sem palavras. 
Aparentemente, é impossível entrar na universidade após ser banido e com um dos professores lá dentro. 
Pareceu tão simples pra Cxaxa e Rathuum entrarem naquela noite. Talvez tivessem a ajuda de Lírio ou outra pessoa? Mas pra eles, foi fácil entrar a primeira, e dizem que a segunda também vai ser fácil. Ninguém a não ser eles contam com isso. Cxaxa confirma que não são espiões fazendo perguntas, e descobre que a negra que achou dentro da universidade atrás de seu próprio mistério, e vai atrás dela na feira, pra deixar tudo a limpo. Confirmam a festa daqui alguns dias, e vão para a feria. A acham com sua amiga cadeirante. Cxaxa deixa bem claro que o mistério e dela, e atrito é criado entre as duas.

Depois disso, pouca coisa acontece. Seth conhece a cadeirante, tenta conversar com ela, e a conhece melhor. Rathuum, por sua vez, vai atrás de Artemisia e o vê apanhando feio de Lírio, e o motivo: Aparentemente por se envolver com Miguel. Após apanhar, eles vão para outra festa, onde ele conhece uma garota chamada Mia. 
Eles destroem um carro qualquer de pessoas estranhas de dentro dessa festa, são seguidos por essa pessoa e Rathuum destrói o joelho dele, assim como seu carro. A noite passa com os dois fazendo putaria. 
Seth, a noite, vai até o hospital e tenta investigar os irmãos Tornasol e quem eles visitam no hospital. Eles percebem, mais ou menos, e ficam de olho em  Seth.

No outro dia, Artemisia promete ir a festa dos Tornasol juntos.

column4:
You and Ro somehow get the body back near the New Path garden without much trouble. If anyone saw it, nobody seemed to want to interfere. Maybe that was something with your ""accountment "" to the others about the source. Perhaps the word is out that Bert operates by a different set of rules. 

In either case, you get to the gardens. 

Anslem is there with Alieh. Anslem has several large plastic containers.  Already you can see half the flowers in the garden are revived. Standing tall. It smells wonderful in here. It smells amazing. You know, if you take of the flower again you risk addiction. You're not addicted now. But it certainly calls to you. 

Once Anslem sees you enter he rushes over to you.

""Bert! I got the water as Jules said, but ... what is wrong with her? It was like....""

Then Anslem sees the corpse. He is lost for words.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p><strong>""Bert! I got the water as Jules said, but ... what is wrong with her? It was like....</strong>""</p><p>Then Anslem sees the corpse. He is lost for words. </p>

She follows Anslem. Smiling. Relieved. Then she looks down.

""What happened? What did you do?""

There are several members of The New Path here. Rejoicing in the healing of the flowers. All their eyes are on you. 

What do you do?

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>She follows Anslem. Smiling. Relieved. Then she looks down.</p><p>""<strong>What happened? What did you do?</strong>""</p><p>There are several members of The New Path here. Rejoicing in the healing of the flowers. All their eyes are on you. </p><p><strong>What do you do? </strong></p>

Bert takes Anselm's hand and squeezes it gently. It's so good to have him here with them two. One thing at a time, though.

Feeling the pressure of all looks on them, Bert draws a deep, still painful breath and stands tall. This isn't going to be easy.

""When I got there, the fight was mostly over. I were already too late. Ro was in bad shape and Nasak... Nasak had just been shot. I'm sorry to be bringing such bad news,"" they adress The New Path and Alieh.

I'm sorry to be bringing such bad news,</strong>"" they adress <strong>The New Path</strong> and <strong>Alieh</strong>.</p>

Bert blinks at Alieh a couple of times, puzzled.

""Nasak, you know? One of yours...,"" they say.

""You talked Ro into rescuing him.""
<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Bert blinks at Alieh a couple of times, puzzled.</p><p>""Nasak, you know? One of yours...,"" they say.</p><p>""You talked Ro into rescuing him.""</p>

Alieh does not look sad, nor angry. 

She looks worried. 

The worshipers of the New Path slither over like a uniform sheet of oil, they gather Nasak's body and take it to  the composting area. In death, his body will feed the flower. 

She looks to Ro. 

""Thank you, for trying."" 

What do you do?

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Alieh does not look sad, nor angry. </p><p>She looks worried. </p><p>The worshipers of the New Path slither over like a uniform sheet of oil, they gather Nasak's body and take it to  the composting area. In death, his body will feed the flower. </p><p>She looks to Ro. </p><p>""<strong>Thank you, for trying</strong>."" </p><p><strong>What do you do?</strong></p>

""Yeah, well...,"" they start scratching their neck and then just nod.

Bert watches the New Path begin their rituals of death. They look at Ro, standing next to them and lightly touch their friend's arm.

""Would you like to stay?""

Burials are for the living, to say goodbye, find closure, to move on eventually. This is about what Ro wants. They'll follow their wishes.

""If Ro wants to participate, they are more than welcome. But they will need to partake of the flower.""
<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>""<strong>If Ro wants to participate, they are more than welcome. But they will need to partake of the flower.</strong>"" </p>

Ro stands frozen. The situation's becoming real to them. Ro doesn't look at you. Maybe Ro's in shock. 

It sounds like you're trying to Read Ro? 

Even without a Read it is obvious if you gave Ro a nudge they would go, take the flower, join the death rites. You could Read a Sitch to see what would become of that? 

What do you do?

""Ro...,"" Bert says softly, delicately, keeping their hand on their friend's arm.

Seeing the preparations progress, the whole thing becomes more real to Bert, too. This is it. Someone they know, felt something for, even if they didn't like him, really died, is dead, is going to be buried.

They give Ro's arm a comforting squeeze.

""If you'd like to stay, I'll be right next to you. I don't know what the petals do. They do open your mind and they're so potent that you'll want more.""

An involuntary frisson runs down their back. They feel it, the tug of the Flower, not yet a demanding pull. They watch some more, giving their friend all the time they need to decide.

Watching the death rites, Bert wants to know: What should they be on the lookout for?

The Death Rites have never been conducted with flowers full of fresh, powerful source water. 

All who participate will have an intense experience, and it will last longer than they realize. They will come to desire the source water, nay-- some could come to covet the source water. Watch out for that. 

Ro, being so intimate with the Source water, might have an intense and vivid experience, much like yours.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p><strong>Watching the death rites, Bert wants to know: What should they be on the lookout for?</strong></p><p>The Death Rites have never been conducted with flowers full of fresh, powerful source water. </p><p>All who participate will have an intense experience, and it will last longer than they realize. They will come to desire the source water, nay-- some could come to covet the source water. Watch out for that. </p><p>Ro, being so intimate with the Source water, might have an intense and vivid experience, much like yours. </p>

Watching Ro, Bert wonders what Ro wishes Bert would do.

Ro wants to do this death rite thing, not so much for any other reason than for closure, and they want to do it alone. Private. They want Bert to let them step-aside for a moment. 

But, deeper, you can sense that Ro wants instructions. Ro wants a project, something to do, something difficult but meaningful. Something they can give all their focus. Though, independent too.  Ro wants a mission to support the source. To show loyalty to Bert and the source community.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p><strong>Watching Ro, Bert wonders what Ro wishes Bert would do.</strong></p><p>Ro wants to do this death rite thing, not so much for any other reason than for closure, and they want to do it alone. Private. They want Bert to let them step-aside for a moment. </p><p>But, deeper, you can sense that Ro wants instructions. Ro wants a project, something to do, something difficult but meaningful. Something they can give all their focus. Though, independent too.  Ro wants a mission to support the source. To show loyalty to Bert and the source community. </p>

""Alright then,"" they give Ro a peck on the cheek, ""I'll be waiting for you.""

They don't tell Ro to be careful, but it's taken for granted in their lingering touch and the concerned look that searches theirs. They've an idea for what Ro could do when they return. 

Bert breaks contact and moves aside, to leave the New Path's domain. They motion with their head to Anselm.

<Let's go and give them some space.>

Stuffing their hands into their pockets, they nod good-bye to Alieh, and then get on their way. The new developments, the new correspondence of the plants, no the Flowers, and the Source's waters, they find them disconcerting. They hope Ro'll get what they need with the help of the petals and their own ties and not just fall prey to this other's power. Bert'll rip those ensnaring, sanguivorous threads apart, if they have to.

""Never seen Ro like that. Never seen Jules like that. Guess it's time for me to go off the deep end too, eh?""

Anslem cracks a joke. Trying to cheer you up. He starts listing off wacky absurd things he's going to try. Until you laugh, or, at least smile. 

Where is it you're going?

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>""<strong>Never seen Ro like that. Never seen Jules like that. Guess it's time for me to go off the deep end too, eh?""</strong></p><p>Anslem cracks a joke. Trying to cheer you up. He starts listing off wacky absurd things he's going to try. Until you laugh, or, at least smile. </p><p><strong>Where is it you're going? </strong></p>

""Suppose, we could be the wacky quartett then,"" Bert tries for a joke themselves and pulls Anselm into a sideways hug. ""What should we call ourselves?""

Should he be paying attention to Bert when they embrace him, he'd notice that they'd been putting on a show for the New Path, a mask that they're now allowing themselves to slightly slip. They're tired from the after-effects of the poison, a bit shaky even, their feet drag a little, their skin is flushed, and there's a hint of death on their breath. 

Steering them both back to the Source, to look after Jules, they continue to lean into Anselm not only out of camaraderie, as would seem to everyone else, and also onto him for support.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>""<strong>Suppose, we could be the wacky quartett then</strong>,"" Bert tries for a joke themselves and pulls Anselm into a sideways hug. ""<strong>What should we call ourselves?</strong>""</p><p>Should he be paying attention to Bert when they embrace him, he'd notice that they'd been putting on a show for the New Path, a mask that they're now allowing themselves to slightly slip. They're tired from the after-effects of the poison, a bit shaky even, their feet drag a little, their skin is flushed, and there's a hint of death on their breath. </p><p>Steering them both back to the Source, to look after <strong>Jules</strong>, they continue to lean into Anselm not only out of camaraderie, as would seem to everyone else, and also onto him for support.</p>

Anslem lets you steer the both of you back to the Source, but at a certain point he grips you and starts you along a different path. You know where he's taking you. 

""Nope. Nope. Nope. No more work for you. You need some downtime.""

Anslem always means one place when he says downtime. 

""I just heard about how Damson blasted that Nasak jerk and I need a drink. You were there. You saw it. You must need a drink.""

Where is Anslem trying to take you and what is your favorite thing about that place? 

What do you do?

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Anslem lets you steer the both of you back to the Source, but at a certain point he grips you and starts you along a different path. You know where he's taking you. </p><p><strong>""Nope. Nope. Nope. No more work for you. You were there. You saw it. You must need a drink.""</strong></p><p><strong>Where is Anslem trying to take you and what is your favorite thing about that place? </strong></p><p><strong>What do you do? </strong></p>

""Now, now, com'on,"" Bert chides mildly when they realise where Anselm is leading them both. How did he hear so fast what happened at Damson's anyway?

Bert slows them down, not exactly getting them back on track. They'd like to go to his private place and get a drink to take on the way there. His little cave carved into the cliff face is peaceful, quiet, and away from all the trouble of the city it looks down on from high up while also offering a view of the vastness beyond. 

Could be some forgotten people actually hewed it from the stone and built a home there, with the roots of the old, gnarled tree on top as a ladder, and ropy handholds in addition to the crags in the rock. Could be nature did it herself, split the stone and smoothed the walls with water. 

Bert can't tell, only that someone, probably Anselm, furnished this cave with bare necessities, like a cot and comfy chairs, moonshine and pickles in nicked jars, non-perishables, blankets, an old music player and discs, a few cracked vases with dried desert flowers. It's his home now, his safe haven where he goes to be alone or enjoy good company.

""You said something's wrong with Jules. I need to go see her.""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>""Now, now, com'on,"" Bert chides mildly when they realise where Anselm is leading them both. How did he hear so fast what happened at Damson's anyway?</p><p>Bert slows them down, not exactly getting them back on track. It's his home now, his safe haven where he goes to be alone or enjoy good company.</p><p>""You said something's wrong with Jules. I need to go see her.""</p>

""Maybe not wrong, just weird.""

""Like, she told me to bring the water. Then she started pacing all about the source waters. And I swear she was counting her steps. Like she was making a detailed map of the place, in her head.""

Before this, what was the weirdest thing Jules was known for? 

Anslem stops. He takes a deep breath. He is worried about you, but he also knows,from that tone of your voice, when you said you ""need"" to go see her, that he's not going to win. 

He pivots and makes his way back to the Source, but now he's not dragging his feet, exactly, but he's definitely walking slower.

He takes a deep breath. He is worried about you, but he also knows,from that tone of your voice, when you said you ""need"" to go see her, that he's not going to win. </p><p>He pivots and makes his way back to the Source, but now he's not dragging his feet, exactly, but he's definitely walking slower. </p>

""Sorry, I didn't mean to upset you,"" Bert apologises and hugs him a bit more firmly. 

They must not have realised he's something on his mind when he invited them for a drink. They've been neglecting Jules and him too much over all those preparations for the meet of PTB and SL-5.

""Tell you what, I'll make sure Jules is ok, doesn't need help, and then we go for that drink,"" they offer.

""I'm just worried and this doesn't sound more weird than Jules usually is. Not like that time when she brought those spray cans full of white powder and said it's crisis-mass, or something, so it needs to be white everywhere. You remember? Or when she wanted to give everyone flowers while we're at that shoot-out a few weeks ago. We just managed to keep her from running in there and giving everybody a hug.""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>""<strong>Sorry, I didn't mean to upset you</strong>,"" Bert apologises and hugs him a bit more firmly. </p><p>They must not have realised he's something on his mind when he invited them for a drink. They've been neglecting Jules and him too much over all those preparations for the meet of PTB and SL-5.</p><p>""<strong>Tell you what, I'll make sure Jules is ok, doesn't need help, and then we go for that drink,</strong>"" they offer.</p><p>""<strong>I'm just worried and this doesn't sound more weird than Jules usually is. Or when she wanted to give everyone flowers while we're at that shoot-out a few weeks ago. We just managed to keep her from running in there and giving everybody a hug.</strong>""</p>

""It'll take more than looking after Jules to upset me, Bert."" He smiles. Glad you care. Not said in any judgmental or defensive way. More of a ""don't worry about me, let me worry about you!"" sort of way. 

He grabs your hand and spins you around, slowly. Like you were mid-dance-step. But with that unconscious grace that Anslem has, that's so infectious. But with that spin, he points you back toward the source. 

""You're right. It'll be nothing.""

And then he's walking, quickly. Pulling you along. Singing one of his favorite songs. But with the lyrics all messed up-- replaced with talk of Jules and steps, and white powder and such. A song packed full of inside jokes just for the two of you.

But with the lyrics all messed up-- replaced with talk of Jules and steps, and white powder and such. A song packed full of inside jokes just for the two of you. </p>

Tell us what it's like going back to the Source. I think we've done this before, but it's fun to see. Like a quick montage of entering the source. What key features does the camera linger on, (to let us know their importance?)

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p><strong>Tell us what it's like going back to the Source. I think we've done this before, but it's fun to see. Like a quick montage of entering the source. What key features does the camera linger on, (to let us know their importance?)</strong></p>

A wide smile lights up their face when Anselm spins them around and they chuckle when he makes up that song. People say, they're always so serious, too serious maybe. But with Anselm joking with them, they can't help but feel better already.

The two of them have passed out of the old city, or rather its remants, by now. There are many routes in and out. The path they take, isn't more than a deer track, trampled dirt, through some scarce vegetation, shrubs, dry trees, and drier grass, that leads into the surrounding hills. The entrance to the cave system is hidden behind some of that vegetation which is greener, more plenty here than down below. 

Usually, Ro or sometimes even Damson would welcome visitors. Today, Magali is standing further in, in some concealed corner, in the darkness by the entry point, to keep watch and either scare them away or let them pass. Thin and bony, long knife through the belt, she reveals herself by removing the cover of a small lantern. They exchange greetings and Anselm and Bert pass into the dark, winding tunnels, taking another lamp with them. Bert wouldn't need a light, knowing the way by heart and letting the Source pull them along. Still, it's comforting to be able to also perceive the inconspicuous markings that show the way if you know what to look for. Otherwise, you would pass right by the fissures and seemingly crumbled horizontal shafts that you've to squeeze or crawl through or you'd loose your way in the labyrinth of dead ends while getting further in on the downward sloping track.

Gradually, luminous spots appear on the walls which eventually become gently glowing filaments and veins running through the moist surface of the stones while the air gets markedly cooler compared to the stiffling heat outside. Finally, the tunnels get wider and you hear dripping and drops hitting the first catch-tarps and jugs collecting water coming from the ceiling and flowing in occasional rivulets from cracks in the luminiscent walls. Even further in, some pieces of ancient tiles still adorn the smooth surfaces here and there speaking of hallways, alcoves, and in-ground basins for bathing or storing water set in the vaulted caverns beneath the mountains. 

It is here where the first traces of actual habitation can be seen. People live here or at least rest here or come to meet and eat and drink the icy water, sitting on the floor, on cushions, blankets, and foot-stools around low tables, illuminated by the biolumiscent algae in the pools and the light filtering through the pannelled ceiling.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>A wide smile lights up their face when Anselm spins them around and they chuckle when he makes up that song. People say, they're always so serious, too serious maybe. But with Anselm joking with them, they can't help but feel better already.</p><p>The two of them have passed out of the old city, or rather its remants, by now. There are many routes in and out. The path they take, isn't more than a deer track, trampled dirt, through some scarce vegetation, shrubs, dry trees, and drier grass, that leads into the surrounding hills. The entrance to the cave system is hidden behind some of that vegetation which is greener, more plenty here than down below. </p><p>Usually, Ro or sometimes even Damson would welcome visitors. Today, Magali is standing further in, in some concealed corner, in the darkness by the entry point, to keep watch and either scare them away or let them pass. Thin and bony, long knife through the belt, she reveals herself by removing the cover of a small lantern. They exchange greetings and Anselm and Bert pass into the dark, winding tunnels, taking another lamp with them. Bert wouldn't need a light, knowing the way by heart and letting the Source pull them along. Still, it's comforting to be able to also perceive the inconspicuous markings that show the way if you know what to look for. Otherwise, you would pass right by the fissures and seemingly crumbled horizontal shafts that you've to squeeze or crawl through or you'd loose your way in the labyrinth of dead ends while getting further in on the downward sloping track.</p><p>Gradually, luminous spots appear on the walls which eventually become gently glowing filaments and veins running through the moist surface of the stones while the air gets markedly cooler compared to the stiffling heat outside. Finally, the tunnels get wider and you hear dripping and drops hitting the first catch-tarps and jugs collecting water coming from the ceiling and flowing in occasional rivulets from cracks in the luminiscent walls. Even further in, some pieces of ancient tiles still adorn the smooth surfaces here and there speaking of hallways, alcoves, and in-ground basins for bathing or storing water set in the vaulted caverns beneath the mountains. </p><p>It is here where the first traces of actual habitation can be seen. People live here or at least rest here or come to meet and eat and drink the icy water, sitting on the floor, on cushions, blankets, and foot-stools around low tables, illuminated by the biolumiscent algae in the pools and the light filtering through the pannelled ceiling.</p>

As you pass through the halls and corridors you bring a sense of relief to everyone. They see you and they all break into a smile. Each greets or acknowledges you in some way or other. 

Jules is not in her room. 

It takes some time to find her. Asking around, you learn she moved throughone of the narrow passages, where the incline up makes it just a bit too onerous to really use that section of the Source caves, she's found another nook. It is a bit of a climb and needs some weird contortions to get through some gaps, but eventually this path opens to a wide area. Low ceiling. 

Jules is in the middle of it asleep. 

Some of the walls have some writing and etching on them. The luminescent algae here glow a deep orange and red.

Low ceiling. </p><p>Jules is in the middle of it asleep. </p><p>Some of the walls have some writing and etching on them. The luminescent algae here glow a deep orange and red.  </p>

Carca is next to the opening. He's standing watch. Though it is unclear if he's protecting her, or keeping track of her. 

""She's been asleep for a very long time. She was wandering about, and then Isami showed up, wanted some water, and she turned him away. She was shouting. Ranting really.""

He looks at you with serious eyes.

""She was acting like she had a grudge against him....""

 Isami is a scientist. Known for various things. Known to deal with artifacts as well. Might move in the same circles as Verez and Dariz. 

Carca says grudge with the gravity, as if Jules broke the rules of the source, in his mind at least. 

What do you do?

She was wandering about, and then Isami showed up, wanted some water, and she turned him away. She was shouting. Ranting really.</strong>""</p><p>He looks at you with serious eyes.</p><p><strong>""She was acting like she had a <em>grudge</em> against him....""</strong></p><p> Isami is a scientist. Known for various things. Known to deal with artifacts as well. Might move in the same circles as Verez and Dariz. </p><p>Carca says grudge with the gravity, as if Jules broke the rules of the source, in his mind at least. </p><p><strong>What do you do? </strong></p>
Hey, we've just met Carca in the fiction. But Bert's dealt with him before. He broke a rule once, didn't he. What was it and what was his punishment?

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Hey, we've just met Carca in the fiction. But Bert's dealt with him before. H<strong>e broke a rule once, didn't he. What was it and what was his punishment? </strong></p>

Bert looks at Carca for a moment, bewildered. They can't imagine Jules holding grudges nor ranting; at least not unless that person did something very terrible, but even then...

Breaking the Source's rules, however, Carca wouldd know of course. He had once harmed another guest and since the aussaulted kept visible marks, no matter they were small, Carca was disfigured himself and made to give up the little finger on his left hand.

Bert puts a re-assuring hand on his shoulder as they move past him to relieve him of his felt duty. 

""Thanks for being watchful, Carca.""

They squat down next to Jules and study her sleeping form, watching over her, watching her with more than their eyes for signs that have brought on this unusual behaviour. Then they nudge her to gently rouse her awake after Carca has left.

""Jules?"" they enquire softly.
dice roll

column4:
Verez slides the needle into Dariz's arm. His pupils go wide. He takes in a breath of relief. 

Several hours have passed since the deal with Ro and Nasak. You're back in the coop, door locked. Despite all the fighting and gunshot, nobody's come around. This place is pretty remote. 

Helicopters continue to buzz about the city more than usual. None of them have flown overhead.

column1: <div id=""messages-region"" class=""roleplay-messages span_12""><div><div class=""message-list""><div class=""message"" id=""message-323083""><div class=""row"">

""OK, Dariz. There you are. You feel better now?"" 

She smiles and strokes his forehead. 

""It's time. Tell me the code to the safe. We don't get it now, SL-5 will.""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>""<strong>OK, Dariz. There you are. You feel better now?</strong>"" </p><p>She smiles and strokes his forehead. </p><p>""<strong>It's time. Tell me the code to the safe. We don't get it now, SL-5 will.</strong>"" </p>

Dariz looks at Verez. Then to you. Then back to Verez. ""Yeah, SL-5 bastards.""

Then, looking at you one final time you can see that click of trust in his mind. 

If you spend your hold he will tell Verez the code. Or, on a word from you, he will wait and tell only you. You can just see it in his eyes. Verez can see it too though. 

What do you do?

""<strong>Yeah, SL-5 bastards</strong>.""</p><p>Then, looking at you one final time you can see that click of trust in his mind. </p><p>If you spend your hold he will tell Verez the code. column3: End of Session 2 - Tor and Sisqo

column4:
When Dee Dee appeared in her robe and fuzzy slippers, she explained that Dana was her sister.  Dana was Dee Dee’s little sister and was something of a bounty hunter, but also traveled with Dee Dee.  The two of them seemed to both be well-read (as Tor had discovered in his early discussions with Dana), though their origins and the source of this knowledge was not immediately known or hinted at.

Sisqo quickly put two and two together and was able to piece together that Dee Dee was THE renown Dee Dee of Seattle fame; a woman who had travelled extensively throughout the city cataloguing people and places in a series of written journals (that Sisqo had probably not read as thoroughly as he might have).  Tor had not heard of Dee Dee given his being a relatively new arrival … though, he may not want to admit to this since it seems everyone (Scarlet, Dylan and Gemma, included) besides Stokes knew who the young woman was.  Stokes seemed as bewildered as Tor, though Stokers seemed less reserved about exhibiting his lack of understanding.

Uncle Lin had an offer for them: A retrieval mission of a sort. In exchange for his assistance with Dana’s recovery (and paying for a Healer from Bell Town to assist) it seemed that he wanted their assistance in retrieving a cargo somewhere outside the environs of the city.  Perhaps there was still room for negotiation on this point.  It also seemed that Uncle Lin might have additional information on the “contract” concerning Hope.

Dylan was set on his goal of making the girl safe and announced that he would disappear with the girl for a while.  He said he would stop by and talk to October, and then would be gone.  He would only pass word through October and no one else and would make those arrangements with her.

Gemma and Stokes agreed to re-supply and then look into Zayden and Thor, and this bounty they had on Hope.  Though, Gemma said that she would have to run a mission or two on the side to gain some jingle to support the endeavor.  Stokes seemed not to have such concerns and only stated that he would be ready to go with her in a few days.  In short, the two of them figured they might be on their way in a week - maybe two.

Eventually, Sisqo and Tor were permitted to see Dana.  She was unconscious.  The old healer, Oboe, 

hovered by the girl’s side.  Dana’s color was pale.  There were clear tubes with fluid, and even what appeared to be blood from a glass bottle running into the girl.  Dana looked younger than she had before.  In this state she seemed almost a teenager, yet she had to have been in her early twenties, hadn’t she?  In this condition, Dana no longer looked like the tough woman she made airs to be, but a vulnerable, pretty, very ill, girl.  Uncle Lin’s people had the items that Oboe needed to help Dana, but they were expensive.  Sisqo and Tor knew that the bill would be high.  Maybe they would not want to profess such a close relationship to the girl after all?

[What do they want to do about Dana’s situation?  Do they distance themselves?  Will they agree to assist Uncle Lin soon?  In the near term, what do they hope to do?] 

SESSION END:At the end of every session, choose a character who knows you better than they used to. If there’s more than one, choose one at your whim. Tell that player to add +1 to their Hx with you on their sheet. If this brings them to Hx+4, they reset to Hx+1 (and therefore mark experience). If no one knows you better, choose a character who doesn’t know you as well as they thought, or choose any character at your whim. Tell that player to take -1 to their Hx with you on their sheet. If this brings them to Hx -3, they reset to Hx=0 (and therefore mark experience).

column3: Jump to last post

column1: <div id=""messages-region"" class=""roleplay-messages span_12""><div><div class=""message-list""><div class=""message"" id=""message-323248""><div class=""row"">

Having assumed that the terms agreed to by Gemma and Stokes included him anyway Tor does not think twice about it, it sounds like fun, and if that is all it costs... brilliant. And if those two were dealing with the local bounty problem he would cover for them.

Plus, if Uncle Lin wanted something from outside the city he would need someone who had been out there anyway. All the locals seemed scared of the outside, worried that being out there would drive them mad. Tor does not see that there is any reason to worry, he had been out there and it had not done him any harm... he sticks a finger in his ear, waggles it a little and then tastes the earwax... Still tastes sane to me. He thinks with a shrug.

Oboe seemed to know her stuff, and there was a lot he could learn from her --his expertise being mainly in battlefield medicine and not long-term care-- so he earns his keep by helping her, offering suggestions where he feels he can contribute and watching. He had tried speaking to Lin about the bad air, sanitation and general heath of his people (""Sunlight is good for you""), but he is not sure he was taken seriously and far be it from him to tell another man how to run things in his own house.

He is pleased to have retrieved one of the shirts he used for Dana's dressings from the scrap-heap, one he had cut up for bandages but this one is silk, and was a gift from his mother. Even after three washes, the blood has left a new pattern on the previously navy-blue fabric, and it is now more of a burgundy... he thinks he likes it.

He has not had much time to speak with Dee Dee aside from the standard condolences and such, and he is a little intimidated by her. A real-life writer! Someone who maybe makes the books he loves so much? He is not even sure how that is possible.

The best reward from this outing --well aside from a little girl saved... but that is the job-- is his newfound friendship with Sisqo. Tor likes the man, but more importantly he thinks he can trust him, and that is worth more in this world than all the toilet paper he can carry (and yes, he is still pining a little in the godaweful place).

column4:
Hooch and his boys quickly made the Earthworm their new home.  Tuck had possessed ample unused space in the surrounding buildings, but had only a small handful of employees to enforce his claim to the structures surrounding it.  The presence of Hooch’s gang enabled him to finally move out the squatters who had been making a mess of the place.  They soon entered into a symbiotic relationship where Hooch’s boys would be permitted to make their base of operations there in exchange for keeping the place secure.  Reluctantly, Tuck agreed to offer up food and drink “at cost”, but even after a couple of days, there were rumblings among the boys that “at cost” was only a little lower than they might normal have to settle for.

Only time would tell whether or not this arrangement would work out.  Though, the loser in any dispute would almost certainly be Tuck.

Three days into their stay, Tuck got called away to a hold in Bell town at the request of the local Angel, someone name of Oboe.  Hooch had already heard the story how Tuck had taken to the ancient art of “barbering” which meant he had some sort of doctoring skill.  Not the type of doctoring skill with poultices, potions, and old medicines, but with knives and bloodletting of a sort.  The old man didn’t seem so steady these days and Hooch might not be certain HE would feel comfortable with the old man waving a sharp instrument near him, but, apparently someone in Bell Town felt he might be useful.

After a couple of days, Tuck returned from the hold of a local man name of Uncle Lin.  Tuck told of a girl who had been injured in a fight with Barkers and was nearly dead when he arrived.  Tuck recounted a proud tale of how he saved the girl’s life, and described in detail how he had re-inflated a lung and put some parts and pieces of the girl back together.  He even went so far to say that he had actually been sober for two days!  Though, he hinted that there was no alcohol available to him, so that may have been the why of it.

Tuck also mentioned rumors of something of value outside the town that Uncle Lin was interested in.  The old sawbones and bar owner had no great interest in gathering further details, but the story did pique the interest of a few of the boys.

[Is Hooch going to allow this “partnership” to continue for the short term?  Or, is he going to step in and claim ownership of the Earthworm and all of it sooner rather than later?  How is he going to treat with his new neighbors in Bell Town?  Hooch’s gang might be hard to corral as time goes on, but they have enough loot from the Barkers to keep themselves busy for the moment.]

[Session 3 will begin in the furtherance of one or more of these matters, and may involve a roll or new decisions to make]

SESSION END: Hooch didn’t really engage enough with the other PCs to justify a change in Hx.

column1: Back to Top

column4: The scrap of data that brought you here was thin, a mapping chip bought

column1: off a seedy underworld fixer happy to watch the Guild finance his
payday, but it would seem to be correct so far. The decryption led to a
Nav Beacon who's code has been singing gently to your computer for the last three weeks all the
way through the black, until the world of Riskan Four rose ahead of

you, vast polar ice fields glittering over more than half the planet from the light of the dull reddish sun. Autopilot follows the signal slowly into the atmosphere, directly toward a swirling vortex.

As the ship enters the atmosphere of Riskan Four the shaking gets more and more violent. The approach through the icy storms of the atmosphere drill physical visibility down to only a few meters and the autopilot chimes gently with the Manual Override Request, known affectionately to many experienced pilots as the ""Get the hell on the Stick"" noise.

Why couldn't they have waited a few orbits until the storm had passed? It was too late now, and complaining about it wouldn't help anything. She'd just have to make sure to check the weather before they started entry next time.

Selena checked the straps of her chair and tightened a few, better uncomfortable tight for a while instead of too loose. On some other ship she'd probable be handling the sensors, but on this vessel the pilot and ship being melded made that redundant.

""Aran, do you need anything."" Still it was good to ask, in the off chance she could be useful.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Why couldn't they have waited a few orbits until the storm had passed? It was too late now, and complaining about it wouldn't help anything. She'd just have to make sure to check the weather before they started entry next time.</p><p>Selena checked the straps of her chair and tightened a few, better uncomfortable tight for a while instead of too loose. On some other ship she'd probable be handling the sensors, but on this vessel the pilot and ship being melded made that redundant.</p><p>""Aran, do you need anything."" Still it was good to ask, in the off chance she could be useful.</p>

Aran is dozing when the autopilot alarm startles her awake.  She has barely left the cockpit the last twenty-four hours anticipating this moment.  The weather scans indicate this to be the most opportune window for atmospheric entry to avoid the more brutal aspects of the storm's fury.  But the high spin rate of Riskan Four...well that was going to cause them to come in hot and fast.  Hotter than you normally want to skim atmosphere.  Too fast and they would be pulled right over the horizon and break atmosphere, if they were lucky that's all they would break.  Come in to slow, even by a few hundred klicks per hour, they would drop to soon and be driven into the center of the massive storm vortex that was currently buffeting them at its edge.  She must bring them in at just the right speed and just the right timing to bounce over the vortex, which should put them in orbit almost on top of the Nav Beacon they had been following to this forsaken planet.  She is checking the read outs on hull integrity when Selena asks,  ""Aran, do you need anything?"" 

""Kiran, No!"" she barks at Selena.  ""I don't need this right now!  But maybe having her on sensors wouldn't be such a bad idea.""  she thinks to herself.  Aran is supposed to be in sync with the new AI the Guild was testing.  But she hates that alien tech, it makes her feel like something is inside her.  However, the extra pay grade she gets from being a Guild lab rat is to much to reject.  ""Strap in!  Everyone strap in, and I mean it Kosmik!""  the strain in her voice is obvious to the rest of the crew.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Aran is dozing when the autopilot alarm startles her awake.  She has barely left the cockpit the last twenty-four hours anticipating this moment.  The weather scans indicate this to be the most opportune window for atmospheric entry to avoid the more brutal aspects of the storm's fury.  But the high spin rate of Riskan Four...well that was going to cause them to come in hot and fast.  Hotter than you normally want to skim atmosphere.  Too fast and they would be pulled right over the horizon and break atmosphere, if they were lucky that's all they would break.  Come in to slow, even by a few hundred klicks per hour, they would drop to soon and be driven into the center of the massive storm vortex that was currently buffeting them at its edge.  She must bring them in at just the right speed and just the right timing to bounce over the vortex, which should put them in orbit almost on top of the Nav Beacon they had been following to this forsaken planet.  She is checking the read outs on hull integrity when Selena asks,  <strong>""Aran, do you need anything?"" </strong></p><p><strong>""Kiran, No!""</strong> she barks at Selena.  ""<em>I don't need this right now!  But maybe having her on sensors wouldn't be such a bad idea."" </em> she thinks to herself.  Aran is supposed to be in sync with the new AI the Guild was testing.  But she hates that alien tech, it makes her feel like something is <em>inside</em> her.  However, the extra pay grade she gets from being a Guild lab rat is to much to reject.  <strong>""Strap in!  Everyone strap in, and I mean it Kosmik!""</strong>  the strain in her voice is obvious to the rest of the crew.                   </p>

Somewhere aboard the shuddering ship a missing section of handrail testified as to why the Jovian was singled out in Aran's announcement, as did a shoulder-shaped depression in the galley floor. ""That bad out there is it?"" Krit replied via one of the wall-mounts scattered throughout the interior, notable only for the fact it was not a fixture of her room. ""I trust you."" Three little words her crewmates had by now come to associate with the little kick to the heart adrenaline gave them whenever Ms. Kosmik was in the midst of tempting fate.

The pilot's display confirmed it, revealing Krit's whereabouts as the yet undinged laundry room.

Touring the GVL circuit had been an entirely different animal and simply put the precision-grown athlete was not as accomplished a sleeper as her compeers. That she required a great deal less of it than the others often left her restless in the last leg of these long journeys, to the point that she'd pounce on even the least time sensitive chores at the most inopportune moments. Moments like now, her azure eyes transfixed on the polymer beads agitating away stains as they swirled wildly within the waterless-washing machine.

""Remember Delta Seuden? Or Khaba? Pretty sure if it was anyone else sitting in that chair of yours we'd all be a part of this ship by now."" she teased, per usual her voice nowhere near as tense as the situation called for. ""And we both know I'd tear through those straps like the tape at a marathon."" Krit argued, a point that nobody save herself seemed to have settled on. ""Besides, the washer's got a handle on it. Don't worry."" she failed to assure, instead conjuring up the likely scenario of shearing the door from the appliance given a good enough bump.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Somewhere aboard the shuddering ship a missing section of handrail testified as to why the Jovian was singled out in Aran's announcement, as did a shoulder-shaped depression in the galley floor. ""That bad out there is it?"" Krit replied via one of the wall-mounts scattered throughout the interior, notable only for the fact it was not a fixture of her room. ""I trust you."" Three little words her crewmates had by now come to associate with the little kick to the heart adrenaline gave them whenever Ms. Kosmik was in the midst of tempting fate.</p><p>The pilot's display confirmed it, revealing Krit's whereabouts as the yet undinged laundry room.</p><p>Touring the GVL circuit had been an entirely different animal and simply put the precision-grown athlete was not as accomplished a sleeper as her compeers. That she required a great deal less of it than the others often left her restless in the last leg of these long journeys, to the point that she'd pounce on even the least time sensitive chores at the most inopportune moments. Moments like now, her azure eyes transfixed on the polymer beads agitating away stains as they swirled wildly within the waterless-washing machine.</p><p>""Remember Delta Seuden? Or Khaba? Pretty sure if it was anyone else sitting in that chair of yours we'd all be a part of this ship by now."" she teased, per usual her voice nowhere near as tense as the situation called for. ""And we both know I'd tear through those straps like the tape at a marathon."" Krit argued, a point that nobody save herself seemed to have settled on. ""Besides, the washer's got a handle on it. Don't worry."" she failed to assure, instead conjuring up the likely scenario of shearing the door from the appliance given a good enough bump.</p>

Aran grits her teeth as Krit rambles on.  ""Stop. Talking."" she mutters as she switches off the comm.  She grips the control yoke and fights against its shuddering as storm shear buffets the ship even harder.  Checking read outs, piloting the ship and calculating entry data is all to much for her to take on alone.  She must sync up.  

A bio-engineered implant, known as the cross embed due to its shape, was surgically inserted into her brain.  This implant, created from alien tech found on a Guild expedition, is a rolling multiple frequency, organic, harmonic generator on a scale never seen before. Another organic based diode was installed into the ships controls.  Aran opens a compartment on the deck, filled with a purple powder.  She exposes the aromatic hydrocarbon derivative to ultra-violet, creating a miasmatic overlay.  Breathing in the gas activates the embed, causing the resonators to couple at almost impenetrable, harmonically secured frequencies.  Her eyes dilate as she becomes a part of the ship and it becomes part of her.  She now shudders from the buffeting of the storm.  Her brain is now calculating the trajectories, fuel usage and timing windows for entry scenarios.  All data reads are instantly available, she is melded with the ship.  ""Greetings Aran, you have returned, you have been missed.""

As they bumped and jolted through the atmosphere Selena pulled a necklace up from around her neck, it was a simple spiral design but useful as a centering tool.

Aran was on edge, perfectly understandable given the circumstance but the pilot needed to be in control of her emotions as much as she needed to be in control of the ship.

Taking calm breaths Selena reached out to touch Aran's mind, trying to help the other woman calm herself so she could better focus on the task of piloting them through the storm raging outside.

Selena centers herself and settles into a peaceful and calm state of mind.  She projects toward Aran, but instead of the familiar psychic connection to which she is accustomed, her reach is blocked.  Selena is confused, this is not a phenomena she has ever experienced.  Suddenly, her mind is filled with a flashing, muddy red aura repelling her...with aggression?

Selena broke the contact abruptly and the necklace dropped back onto her chest as she held a hand to her head. Any sound of pain or string of cursing would just distract Aran more, so she bit down on both reactions.

After a few ragged breathes she returned to the proper breathing of meditation, if she was going to help it obviously wasn't going to be that way.
