He had been thinking about the fact that his stash of dried jhubu flower was running low, and that in turn had coaxed him into a fond reminiscence upon the way in which the jhubu smoke mediated the visions of Fate. Yes, sometimes those visions were lovely indeed...</p><p>But the girl child was still yammering on. What was she saying?  Some nonsense about singing trees. </p><p>""The jhubu tree is sacred, human girl,"" Yorbi called behind him, in a tone that parents reserved for ignorant children to whom things must be explained slowly. ""The Winds of Fate blow through its branches. It grants us the jhubu flower, which as my master told me many years ago, is very fine. Only the jhubu bark will hold the power of the scrawls.""</p><p> The little goblin sighed inwardly. When he saw Girrant again, he would have to tell the dwarf that he did not appreciate being left in the desert to look after two children, both human and bear. He was no nursemaid!</p>
Tharn Aroa’u, of No Clan nor Cave

Tharn made a harrumphing noise. Keeza's wide-eyed imagination was more likely to lead them off a cliff than anywhere useful. 

But he didn't waste the energy on speaking. He was too hot. Everything was hot. Karhu, like bears, didn't sweat, and there were no convenient pools of water for him to sit in for an hour or thirteen. He settled for panting, and occasional gulps of his flask, for all the good that that did. 

About the only thing that was stopping him from heading back was the desert he'd have to cross to get there.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Tharn made a harrumphing noise. Keeza's wide-eyed imagination was more likely to lead them off a cliff than anywhere useful. </p><p>But he didn't waste the energy on speaking. He was too hot. Everything was hot. Karhu, like bears, didn't sweat, and there were no convenient pools of water for him to sit in for an hour or thirteen. He settled for panting, and occasional gulps of his flask, for all the good that that did. </p><p>About the only thing that was stopping him from heading back was the desert he'd have to cross to get there.</p>

A hot wind blew as the trio walked, ruffling Tharn's fur, whipping Yorbi's robes, tousling Keeza's hair. The white sands drifted and shifted around them, stinging their eyes as the gusts picked up, lashing at them. Shielding his face from that assault, the goblin led the way towards distant stacks of massive wind-worn stones that he recognized from one of his dream-times. A jumble of gray-white rocks towering above the sand, their slopes would provide some much needed shade and a place to rest through the worst heat of the day.

It was the ground beneath Yorbi's feet, however, the thumping sound of his staff on the sand, that occupied the little wizard's mind as his companions came to his side. A bit of brushing and swiping with hands, feet and paws revealed the edges of something that the wind had partially uncovered -- a structure of some kind, long buried but now revealed.

What had they found? A long-abandoned dwarven fortification? An ancient Arzethian ruin? Or something much older?

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>A hot wind blew as the trio walked, ruffling Tharn's fur, whipping Yorbi's robes, tousling Keeza's hair. The white sands drifted and shifted around them, stinging their eyes as the gusts picked up, lashing at them. Shielding his face from that assault, the goblin led the way towards distant stacks of massive wind-worn stones that he recognized from one of his dream-times. A jumble of gray-white rocks towering above the sand, their slopes would provide some much needed shade and a place to rest through the worst heat of the day.</p><p>It was the ground beneath Yorbi's feet, however, the thumping sound of his staff on the sand, that occupied the little wizard's mind as his companions came to his side. A bit of brushing and swiping with hands, feet and paws revealed the edges of something that the wind had partially uncovered -- a structure of some kind, long buried but now revealed.</p><p>What had they found? A long-abandoned dwarven fortification? An ancient Arzethian ruin? Or something much older?</p>

Yorbi's stomach growled like a petulant kitten. Due to the excitement of the previous night and the treachery of Girrant's dates, the goblin had had little to eat before they'd set off again. Yes, the ugly little man had left snacks for them before returning to Zeen with the turbaned stranger, but Yorbi had learned to his cost that Girrant's snacks were not to be trusted. What delicious, terrible things now lurked in the wizard's Four Destinies Bag? He was afraid to find out. 

And so when his bare foot brushed some sort of structure beneath the white sand, it suddenly came into Yorbi's head that this must be a storehouse, a cornucopia of the ancients set aside to restore them on their long desert journeys. There would be dried fruits, and meats cured and aged so exquisitely over the centuries of neglect that no goblin had ever set tooth to the like...

Yorbi dropped to his knees. His bone wrap rattled as his little hands worked feverishly to clear sand from whatever lay hidden. Given his size, he made slow progress, but not for lack of effort. 

""Help me, children!"" Yorbi called. ""Look here, Fate has prepared an ancient feast for us in the middle of the desert. Surely it is just beneath these stones!""
dice roll

Yorbi called. ""Look here, Fate has prepared an ancient feast for us in the middle of the desert. Surely it is just beneath these stones!""</p>

Keeza roves over to Yorbi's spot and looks into the little pit he's digging.  ""When you say 'feast,' you mean a literal, actual feast, right?  We're not digging a cat hole, right?  'Cause some things a goblin has to do for himself.""

Then she takes a second look.  ""Hey now.  What's that?

""C'mere, Tharn.  Looks like Yorbi found somebody's lunch.""
dice roll

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Keeza roves over to Yorbi's spot and looks into the little pit he's digging.  ""When you say 'feast,' you mean a literal, actual feast, right?  We're not digging a cat hole, right?  'Cause some things a goblin has to do for himself.""</p><p>Then she takes a second look.  ""Hey now.  What's that?</p><p>""C'mere, Tharn.  Looks like Yorbi found somebody's lunch.""</p>

""Oh, girl child,"" Yorbi chided, without looking up from his work. ""Gheka don't eat cats.""

Although...

Surely there were cats whose meat was not be quite so stringy and sour, after the fashion of carnivores. Perhaps a cat who had chosen for some reason to subsist on grain. Or just a very lazy cat, whose meat had grown soft and fatty from a long habit of indolence. If such a beast happened to run afoul of his hunter's spear, well...

Yorbi shook his head so violently that the tips of his ears quivered. His fingers crooked like claws as he shoveled sand away from whatever was buried beneath.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>""Oh, girl child,"" Yorbi chided, without looking up from his work. ""Gheka don't eat cats.""</p><p>Although...</p><p>Surely there were cats whose meat was not be quite so stringy and sour, after the fashion of carnivores. His fingers crooked like claws as he shoveled sand away from whatever was buried beneath. </p>
Tharn Aroa’u, of No Clan nor Cave

Tharn was so dazed by the sun and heat and sun that it took him a full minute and Keeza's calling of his name to realise that his companions had stopped some way behind him. He turned to see Yorbi digging with his tiny hands, Keeza peering into the hole he was burrowing. 

He was about to call them off their futile search—only Yorbi could sidetrack them from their original sidetrack—when thoughts slowly made their way through his heat-struck brain. A corner meant a building. A building meant a shelter. A shelter meant shade. 

With no little huffing and panting, he began to claw out the hole beside Yorbi.
dice roll

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Tharn was so dazed by the sun and heat and sun that it took him a full minute and Keeza's calling of his name to realise that his companions had stopped some way behind him. He turned to see Yorbi digging with his tiny hands, Keeza peering into the hole he was burrowing. </p><p>He was about to call them off their futile search—only Yorbi could sidetrack them from their original sidetrack—when thoughts slowly made their way through his heat-struck brain. A corner meant a building. A building meant a shelter. A shelter meant shade. </p><p>With no little huffing and panting, he began to claw out the hole beside Yorbi. </p>

It did not take the trio long to determine that their chance find in the desert was no small cache of meat, hidden by passing nomads, no anguished piling of rocks used to mark some unknown grave. This structure was huge, and ancient. The top of the thing was a perfectly square, about ten feet on a side, and perfectly flat. As flat and smooth as the mastercraft stonework of the great Dwarven Citadels that spotted the eastern side of Ashra, in fact. Faded, worn petroglyphs ran around the edge of the tan-colored sandstone, a collection of circles or rings, each containing delicately carved, once brightly painted characters, shapes, and symbols. All three companions recognized the handicraft -- the place was built by the same engineers -- and the same slaves -- who had constructed the Old Empire Road. The place dated back to the age of the Imperial Arzethians, the advanced lizard-race that had once swept out of the desert, conquering all of the continent before magic most foul and black toppled their centuries-old dynasty.

Places like this were thought to hold vast quantities of treasure, the spoils of an Empire grown fat and decadent in the final decades before its downfall... but so too were the reptilian Archons known for their traps, for constructing some of the most fiendish and deadly contraptions ever devised, all to jealously protect the wealth they had stolen from the nations they had crushed.

Between Tharn's brawn, Yorbi's knowledge of all things sandy, and Keeza's indefatigable enthusiasm, the top of the structure was revealed rapidly. The sun overhead punished the excavators, but they still had water enough to fend off the worst of its effects. In less than two hours they unearthed a second level -- an apron of stone that the upper structure squatted upon... perhaps the second level of a massive ziggurat? This would be a find of significance if that was the case, but another detail occupied the adventurers as they cleared sand away from the fourth side of the upper structure.

A massive, ornately carved door stood before them, cracked open enough to allow Yorbi and possibly Keeza to enter. It had once been on rollers so that it could be moved to the side with relative ease, but those stone pins had long been crushed. It would take significant force to move the door to the side. The chamber beyond the door was inky black, and smelled of musty doom, peering eyes and twitching noses revealed...

As more and more of the sandstone structure had been revealed-- more through Tharn's efforts than Yorbi's, it must be admitted-- the goblin's eyes had widened to veritable carbuncles of anticipation. This larder of the ancients was huge! Why, a goblin could swim in the jerky and fruit that such a cyclopean storehouse must hold!  If such a thing were sanitary, and as far as Yorbi was concerned, it was. 

But the smell that wafted from the crack in the door they discovered told a different story. The little wizard was unfamiliar with the smell of doom, but he had some familiarity with the scent of cured meats, and this was decidedly not it. His nose wrinkled. 

""Why would the ancients leave their door open when they left?"" Yorbi lamented. ""Just smell that. All of the food has gone bad.""

Yorbi sized up the space left by the partially opened door, then scuttled blithely through. He was about to plop down just opposite his companions, but the goblin's bare toes brushed cool, open air in the darkness beyond. Yorbi curled his foot and felt gingerly down along the face of the step, until the tips of his toes made contact with the top of the next. 

""I think there are stairs here,"" he hissed through the crack. Standing close to the door, he fished the flints from his Four Destinies Bag and set about lighting his torch-club.
dice roll
Not Tumbling Down Darkened Stairs: 2D6

Keeza doesn’t push Yorbi out of the way so much as she dashes after him and then tries to find the space to get ahead of him and the blinding torch.  “You’d better let me go first!  There could be traps!” she says, much too eager.

""Why don't you let me check it out first?"" is what Tharn didn't say. He didn't get a chance. By the time that he'd expelled a ""Why"", the goblin had scuttled through like a bug, and the cub was halfway to joining him. 

With the emphasis on halfway, by the looks of her wriggly body failing to make anymore headway. 

Tharn let out a long, long long-suffering sigh, and braced himself against the door. One day, when he was part of a Clan and Cave again, he would tell this tale, and nobody would believe him. He didn't even have that going for him.

The whole structure, still half-buried, shuddered as the big bear put a meaty shoulder into the door. Stone-on-stone grinding reverberated throughout the chamber Yorbi had snuck into, and dust and sand drizzled and drifted down from the ceiling as the ancient blocks shifted and vibrated. When Tharn ceased pushing, the opening was wide enough for two Kahrus, or about a dozen Keezas. She slipped through easily, followed by her world-weary, lumbering friend.

Sunlight spilled into the chamber where the stairs led down, adding to the light thrown by the goblin's torch. Here, away from the wind and the blistering sun, it was clear that the stonework was just masterful. Intricately painted carvings lined the stairs and walls, bright yellows and blues and reds contrasting magnificently with the tan of the sandstone. At the bottom of the stairs, probably thirty steps down, two massive doors stood closed. More disconcerting, perhaps, were the scattered rags, rusty weapons, and dusty bones littering the landing...

""Oh, Keeza,"" Yorbi sighed, with an indulgent smile.  ""There are no traps here.  If there were traps, how could the ancient ones get to their food?""  He held his torch-club as high as he could to illuminate the squirming human's plight, but even with his arm at full extension, the flame shone full in the girl's face.  Fortunately, the Karhu's efforts soon freed her.

He really is a very good bear.  Dour, but perhaps he is at an awkward age.  Whatever that is for talking bears.

Turning, Yorbi peered down the stairs; his little eyes widened and glistened at what he saw.  ""Look, children, already there is treasure!"" he cried, pointing at the refuse scattered in front of the doors.  Those bones and scraps of fabric would make welcome additions to Yorbi's bone-wrap!  He was about to scamper down the steps, but something about those long-disused weapons made him pause.  He reconsidered the human child's warning.  As a matter of course Yorbi ignored most things that humans said, but perhaps the girl had a point...

Keeping his weight poised over the top landing, Yorbi fished for the first step and pressed it experimentally with the ball of his foot.  He glanced at the walls, the stairs, not quite expecting anything to happen, but uneasy lest it should.

Keeza and Tharn watched as the torch-wielding, confident (though more cautious than he seemed) goblin walked to the top of the stairs -- and flinched when a dart thwiped out of the wall in front of him, sailing just a few inches over his green head before clattering against the stone wall behind him. A bit of ancient dust drifted in the air as Yorbi froze, his foot still on a slightly loose stone at the top of the steps. Four different holes had appeared in that wall, but only one dart had flown -- the mechanism was as ancient as the structure, and the drifting sands of time had ruined the builders' surprise, preventing the needle's vicious three companions from launching.

There was an audible click as the little mage risked lifting his foot, but no second barrage fired...

Yorbi's ears flattened and he cringed like a whipped dog.  Slowly, he eased his foot off of the first step and back onto the landing.  And there he crouched, stock still, while the tinkling sound of the errant death-needle echoed and died.  

Only when all was still and silent again did he turn his head to eye his companions over one green and effeminate shoulder.  ""I think there are traps!"" he whispered, loudly enough that the corpses at the bottom of the stairs could easily have heard him.

Then the little goblin reviewed the stairs before them.  What had he stepped on, exactly?  Were there other such loose stones on the steps leading down?

His body adjusting to the cool, stilted air of the ziggurat—if that's what it was—made Tharn aware of how hot he had been ... and how thirsty he was. Still, he didn't know when he'd next get the chance, and his companions didn't look like they were in immediate danger. 

As he sipped—definitely a sip, no more than that—he cast one eye over the beautiful carvings on the wall. It reminded him of something in his storehouse of lore (he thought as he sipped again), but if only he could remember what ...

Yorbi knotted his fingers together as he followed Keeza down the steps. His ears pricked, and twitched now and then with his anxiety. It seemed unchivalrous to let the girl child precede him into danger, despite her enthusiasm and breezy confidence. But the little wizard comforted himself with the thought that there were quite a few humans in Zeen, and still more in the larger cities that dotted the desert like rotting fruit fallen from some great tree. In the worst case, they probably wouldn't miss just one. 

Yorbi had little to say to the credit of humans, but they were remarkably good at breeding. 

""Are there traps?"" Yorbi hissed over Keeza's shoulder as they went. ""There are traps, aren't there?""

Keeza beams at the opportunity to prove herself useful, but to be honest, she’s not as good at traps per se as she is at, well, breaking things and putting them back together.  Her grandfather, the jeweler, would hand her clumps of tangled gold and silver chain with the hope of teaching her patience.  “Examine the knot,” he would say.  “When you’re sure what to do, pull out one strand at a time, and if you’ve done the right thing in the right order, the knot will loosen, and the puzzle will grow easier to solve.”

Keeza’s solution was to cut the chains off the knot and piece them together, possibly missing a link or two.

She searches the tunnel, eager to find something to break.
dice roll

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Keeza beams at the opportunity to prove herself useful, but to be honest, she’s not as good at traps per se as she is at, well, breaking things and putting them back together.  Her grandfather, the jeweler, would hand her clumps of tangled gold and silver chain with the hope of teaching her patience.  “Examine the knot,” he would say.  “When you’re sure what to do, pull out one strand at a time, and if you’ve done the right thing in the right order, the knot will loosen, and the puzzle will grow easier to solve.”</p><p>Keeza’s solution was to cut the chains off the knot and piece them together, possibly missing a link or two.</p><p>She searches the tunnel, eager to find something to break.</p>

Avoiding the step that she and Yorbi both believed would spring a trap if it was depressed, Keeza instead monkeyed around inside the groove in the wall that contained the mechanism itself, trying to disable or break the ancient thing by reaching in and--

Tink. Sproing! SLICE!

Screams of pain and a spray of blood filled the air as a rusted blade came violently sweeping out of the slot the young desert-dweller was working in, nearly taking off her hand as it whistled through the air, swinging out at what would be knee-height for someone descending the stairs... which meant Yorbi was in danger of being decapitated!

Yorbi squeaked as the blade's edge swept toward him, neck-high.  It was certain death.  In the space of a breath the goblin's head would surely be bouncing down the stairs, to join the other bones and refuse before the ancients' door...

And then, somehow, he was gone. The cruel device reached its limit and shuddered in empty air.

Because Yorbi had collapsed into a puddle of goblin on the stair, with an ear jutting out here, a bent limb there.  In retrospect, the transformation was remarkable; the creature's little body had gone limb and wobbly, as if all his wee bones had softened to jelly.  He simply oozed under the blade as it passed.

""Girl child!"" the softened goblin-mass whimpered.  ""Are you alive, girl child?""

""Be careful, there's traps!"" came Tharn's voice from up the stairs, where he still was, perusing the carvings. He had never seen the like in his lifetime, although he'd heard stories—there were always stories—and he may never again. 

Looking around, he found, again, that his companions had gone ahead of him, impetuous, and impatient, even as he had been lost in his study. Maybe next time he should invest in a leash, he thought, as he slowly made his way down the stairs.

The scream, and the sight of blood made him lumber a little quicker.

Keeza is gone.  Nothing remains of her in the spot where she stood, only a trickle of fresh blood and her disembodied voice, cursing with such lurid vehemence that every profane syllable bounces against the walls and reverberates in a toneless fugue about the intimate lives of sheep and chickens and someone’s unspecified mother.

Somehow she’s moved from her post near the trap to a spot ten feet thataway, all while cradling her hand to keep blood from dripping onto her good pants.

“I’m all right,” she says, when her repertoire finally fails her.  “Is everybody else okay?”

Yorbi’s head must still be attached to his body, but she would feel awful if her companions were to shed blood because she’d broken the wrong part of the wrong trap.
dice roll

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Keeza is gone.  Nothing remains of her in the spot where she stood, only a trickle of fresh blood and her disembodied voice, cursing with such lurid vehemence that every profane syllable bounces against the walls and reverberates in a toneless fugue about the intimate lives of sheep and chickens and someone’s unspecified mother.</p><p>Somehow she’s moved from her post near the trap to a spot ten feet thataway, all while cradling her hand to keep blood from dripping onto her good pants.</p><p>“I’m all right,” she says, when her repertoire finally fails her.  “Is everybody else okay?”</p><p>Yorbi’s head must still be attached to his body, but she would feel awful if her companions were to shed blood because she’d broken the wrong part of the wrong trap.</p>

""Girl child?"" Yorbi essayed again, feebly.  What was the girl talking about?  Could a chicken do that with a human female?  Perhaps he had been mistaken to strike out into the wilds with these strange creatures. ""My ears are still on,"" he assured her, assuming in his fashion that she would simply understand the goblin expression.  

The wee wizard untangled himself from his pile of body parts on the stair and sat up, rubbing the back of his bare, green skull.  ""Girl child, are you sure that checking for traps is a thing that you do?"" he queried, clearly dubious, but wanting very much to believe.  ""Because the Winds of Fate are whispering to me that this is not a storehouse of tasty ancient food.  This place was built as a slaughterhouse for goblins...""  

Presumably it would function on humans as well.  Perhaps even talking bears.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>""Girl child?"" Yorbi essayed again, feebly.  What was the girl talking about?  Could a chicken <em>do </em>that with a human female?  Perhaps he had been mistaken to strike out into the wilds with these strange creatures. ""My ears are still on,"" he assured her, assuming in his fashion that she would simply understand the goblin expression.  </p><p>The wee wizard untangled himself from his pile of body parts on the stair and sat up, rubbing the back of his bare, green skull.  ""Girl child, are you sure that checking for traps is a thing that you do?"" he queried, clearly dubious, but wanting very much to believe.  ""Because the Winds of Fate are whispering to me that this is not a storehouse of tasty ancient food.  This place was built as a slaughterhouse for goblins...""  </p><p>Presumably it would function on humans as well.  Perhaps even talking bears.</p>

Keeza ties a strip of cloth around her hand, eyeing the depths of the shaft with more respect.  “You don’t put traps like that out unless you’re guarding something amazing.  We should see what it is.”

She throws Yorbi and Tharn a grin and proceeds further into the darkness.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Keeza ties a strip of cloth around her hand, eyeing the depths of the shaft with more respect.  “You don’t put traps like that out unless you’re guarding something amazing.  We should see what it is.”</p><p>She throws Yorbi and Tharn a grin and proceeds further into the darkness.</p>

The flickering light from Yorbi's torch filled the ancient antechamber as the slim, dark-haired girl came back to the steps and descended them again, her hand stinging -- a reminder of the dangers harbored by this ruin. Creeping down the stairs slowly and carefully, she detected no further booby-traps as she arrived at the landing where the bones and other detritus they had seen from the top of the stairs lay. In front of her, two massive, arching doors stood closed. It looked like once they had been covered in brightly painted murals as well, but time had erased most of the work of whatever artisan had labored here. Whereas the walls and stairs were of sandstone, these doors looked bronze.

Keeza's eyes and hands roved the surrounding area as she looked for an opening mechanism, and she frowned when none revealed itself. There no were handles, there was no lock, no switch -- it was almost as though the builders never intended them to be opened after they were sealed...

Tharn Aroa’u, of No Clan nor Cave

""It's most likely a tomb. Not ours,"" he said quickly, at Yorbi's dubious reaction. ""That of an Arzethian mummy. Caution ... more caution would be advised."" 

Tharn made his way to the bottom of the stairs behind Keeza, his back hunching down through the passageway. He studied the door as Keeza felt around for a way through—his ears prickled, it reminded him of something, but what was it?

Tharn relayed what he could remember from Arzethian folklore, keeping his voice low, unsure, even as he did, how much was embroidered by time and tale.

""... and we may not be able to open the door, if they sealed it when they were done. Plus there's almost certainly more traps to keep us from any treasure that they buried with them when they died."" 

Tharn was fairly sure that he couldn't dissuade his inquisitive companions. But perhaps he could, at very least, inject a bit more caution into their approach. 

Plus his intellectual curiosity meant that he was intensely interested in seeing what was behind the door. It's just, well, if what was behind the door had eyes, he'd let Keeza be the first thing that it saw.

Keeza squints into the darkness, trying to discern some kind of door in the slab ahead of her but, hearing Tharn, begins to think this is a job for someone with a pickaxe, rather than a lockpick.  “That’s a pity.”  She toes through the rubble.  “Who puts in deadly traps to guard a wall?  I mean, you’d think the wall would be enough.”

The bronze doors without the handles loomed ominously, all unopened and untested...
<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>The bronze doors without the handles loomed ominously, all unopened and untested...</p>

Yorbi watched Tharn plod past him down the ancient stairs.  Both he and his torch-club were briefly shadowed by the Karhu's bulk, and then torchlight glimmered in the fur across his companion's massive shoulders.  Yorbi considered that if Tharn had reached the bottom intact, there could scarcely be any more dangers for a creature like himself of proper-- that is to say, goblin-- size.  He meandered down as well, to stand with the others among the detritus before the doors.

Yorbi had meant to collect some of the bones and leather scraps for his wrap, but found himself distracted by the great bronze doors stretching high above him.  The little wizard bared his teeth in sudden frustration.  These stupid lizards with their stupid ziggurat had tried to take off his head-- his head-- even though they'd been dead far too long to care, and for what?  To keep him from standing in front of their stupid not-door?

Keeza was right.  It didn't make any sense.  His opinion of the ancients plunged.

Without comment, Yorbi commenced to bang on the door with the butt of his torch-club, using all the strength in his wee arm.  Shadows and light danced crazily about, and the sound of struck bronze quivered into the vault above them.

The whole chamber reverberated when the goblin's staff struck bronze -- reverberated far louder than it seemed it should. Outside, shifting sands slid and cascaded off the outside of the ancient building; inside, sand drizzled from the ceiling, collecting in delicate little mounds that rose from the floor until the vibrations ceased.

But then silence descended again, and it appeared that no one beyond the doors seemed keen to welcome in the unlikely visitors...

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>The whole chamber reverberated when the goblin's staff struck bronze -- reverberated <em>far louder</em> than it seemed it should. Outside, shifting sands slid and cascaded off the outside of the ancient building; inside, sand drizzled from the ceiling, collecting in delicate little mounds that rose from the floor until the vibrations ceased.</p><p>But then silence descended again, and it appeared that no one beyond the doors seemed keen to welcome in the unlikely visitors...</p>

“The curse of the Arzethians has claimed Yorbi’s mind!” Keeza says with unnecessary melodrama, her voice echoing between the bronze reverberations.

But Keeza is less concerned for Yorbi’s last shreds of sanity—what is goblin sanity worth, after all?—than she is with the shifting piles of fine dust.  Water is too precious to spill on the ancient stonework, but maybe the dust will show her where the seams in the wall are.
dice roll

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>“The curse of the Arzethians has claimed Yorbi’s mind!” Keeza says with unnecessary melodrama, her voice echoing between the bronze reverberations.</p><p>But Keeza is less concerned for Yorbi’s last shreds of sanity—what is goblin sanity worth, after all?—than she is with the shifting piles of fine dust.  Water is too precious to spill on the ancient stonework, but maybe the dust will show her where the seams in the wall are.</p>

Turning her keen eye on the doors and the surrounding stone they were set into, Keeza noticed two troubling things as the last of the goblin-created vibrations faded away. First, there were no hinges, or at least none that were visible; second, something weird was going on. Very close to the doors and the seams where they were fitted into the wall, she could see dust and tiny grains of sand suspended in the air, looking like they were frozen there. The blade of her knife proved that they were stuck, as solid in the air as if they were cemented there.

There was sorcery at work here!

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Keeza's suddenly more vigorous investigations yielded no new insights, but the bear and goblin <em>did</em> wonder what the girl was hunched over doing...</p>

Yorbi flattened his ears against his bare skull and eyed the bronze doors balefully.  If those slits of ruby-red had belonged to a creature even marginally taller than he, the portal would have opened on its own out of sheer terror.  As matters stood, nothing happened.

So banging on the door hadn't worked.  Yorbi hadn't really expected it to, but he felt somewhat better for having given the unyielding metal a good goblin thrashing.  He sighed, and his little shoulders sagged, and that's when he noticed Keeza over by the wall, doing something or other with her knife.

He meandered closer to her, bringing the light with him. What was the human doing?  Was she.. ?

""Are you... are you stabbing the wall, girl child?"" he squeaked.  He rolled his little eyes and patiently admonished her, ""Now you can't kill a wall.   It isn't alive, like an ylix, or a bear, which you may certainly stab.  You can stab a wall all day and nothing will happen.""

But she wasn't after the wall, exactly.  She seemed to be poking about just by the wall, and there was something odd there...

Outside...

Tromping down through the shifting sands of a monstrous sand dune, Girrant and his new traveling companion Caho Pae looked at one another as the tracks they'd been following led down to what looked like the top of some ancient, buried structure. Industrious hands and paws had partially exposed the thing, but it was clear most of the massive building remained unearthed. The pair had met just hours before, fending off an attack by a number of armed thugs that came on the heels of the wandering monk asking if he could join Girrant and Sarif on their northbound journey. The two travelers had barely invited the man to join them before they were set upon, and in the confusing melee that ensured the merchant had disappeared, carried off into the wastes by the attackers. The dwarf had thought it best to gather his companions before giving chase, so they had headed south at double time to find his friends...

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p><strong>Outside...</strong></p><p>Tromping down through the shifting sands of a monstrous sand dune, Girrant and his new traveling companion Caho Pae looked at one another as the tracks they'd been following led down to what looked like the top of some ancient, buried structure. Industrious hands and paws had partially exposed the thing, but it was clear most of the massive building remained unearthed. The pair had met just hours before, fending off an attack by a number of armed thugs that came on the heels of the wandering monk asking if he could join Girrant and Sarif on their northbound journey. The two travelers had barely invited the man to join them before they were set upon, and in the confusing melee that ensured the merchant had disappeared, carried off into the wastes by the attackers. The dwarf had thought it best to gather his companions before giving chase, so they had headed south at double time to find his friends...</p>

""Are you sure this is the place?"" Caho says deeply to the dwarf. He licks his lips and shields his eyes from the sun. 

The monk whispers to himself...""Are we seeking looters?""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>""Are you sure this is the place?"" Caho says deeply to the dwarf. He licks his lips and shields his eyes from the sun. </p><p>The monk whispers to himself...""<em>Are we seeking looters?</em>"" </p>

""No,"" Girrand tells his devout companion. ""My former companions headed this way. They are stout allies, but with the sense of fools. If we are to find them, we should rescue them from... here."" 

From his pocket he retrieves some dried scuttleclaw meat. ""Chew this,"" he says. ""For fortitude. It tastes bad, so it must be full of goodness.""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>""No,"" Girrand tells his devout companion. ""My former companions headed this way. They are stout allies, but with the sense of fools. ""As you wish,"" Caho replies. The meat smells a bit odd, but it is not quite as bad as his dwarven companion has warned.

""I trust you..."" Caho checks his satchel and then takes a moment to concentrate on the lines of his palms as wind kicks bits of sand from his fingertips, ""...an ally of yours will be counted as such by myself as well."" the monk continues. 

Gripping his staff and placing the end of it into the shifting ground beneath them, he nods. ""Let us go to our allies,"" he says.

Girrant and Caho Pae made their way to the ziggurat entrance, slipping inside the structure carefully, moving past a huge stone door that had been recently pushed out of place.

They were greeted by a massive form wielding a frightful warhammer -- a hulking, brown-furred beast standing guard as his two friends conferred near the bronze door that remained closed at the bottom of the stairs...

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Girrant and Caho Pae made their way to the ziggurat entrance, slipping inside the structure carefully, moving past a huge stone door that had been recently pushed out of place.</p><p>They were greeted by a massive form wielding a frightful warhammer -- a hulking, brown-furred beast standing guard as his two friends conferred near the bronze door that remained closed at the bottom of the stairs...</p>

An instinctual growl came from Tharn as he whirled around. As he waited for his brave and illustrious companions to, er, finish poking at dust, he had stood guard. His ears were pricked for movement from behind the door, not from behind them. He whirled, about to raise that heavy hammer when ...

... he sniffed something.

Meat. Dried. And there was only one purveyor of such a distinct smell that he'd come across recently. The hammer lowered.

""Girrant of Khyrrand, is that you?""

""Tharn Aroa'u,"" Girrant said, with only the slightest hint in his voice of being pleased to see the karhu. ""I have come to save you from yourselves. I saw traces of blood on the walls as we passed, and assumed at least one of you had perished. I am pleased to see that all are present and correct.""

He coughed slightly, and presented the human monk at his side.

""Tharn Aroa'u Ofnoclannorcave, Yorbi Windblown, Keeza Sharzi --- may I present Caho Pae, whom I met when Sarif and I were headed northwards.""

There was no mention of Sarif's whereabouts.

""An honor,"" Caho says quietly and deeply. He presses a fist against his heart and bows his gaze downward.

Exiting the harsh light of day into this blackness was still playing tricks with his eyes, but the monk attempted to look past the purple and blue spheres circling his vision.

""Three souls... I am glad to see you are intact. I was warned that that might not be the case.""

Caho squints and slowly locks eyes... first with the bear, then the young girl, and finally the goblin.

A sourceless breeze seems to move the man's tattered clothing. He speaks slowly...

""May I be bold enough to ask what you are looking for here that you might forfeit your lives to obtain it?""

“Dust, mostly.  Darkness.  Some sharp things.  And a big wall,” Keeza says.  “Are you good at walls?  ‘Cause Yorbi’s been trying to knock it down with his stick, and I’m not sure walls work like that.”

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>“Dust, mostly.  Darkness.  Some sharp things.  And a big wall,” Keeza says.  “Are you good at walls?  ‘Cause Yorbi’s been trying to knock it down with his stick, and I’m not sure walls work like that.”</p>

Yorbi was in a crouch beside Keeza at the bottom of the stairs, poking at something in the air beside the great doors.  His blood-hued eyes narrowed thoughtfully, and his lips peeled back from the points of his teeth. He made a sound in his throat that might have been a growl coming from a larger creature, but seemed rather like a strangled sort of purr.  

Then he straightened and wheeled, flung his arms wide, and declaimed, ""The Winds of Fate have spoken!  There is sorcery holding this stupid door closed!""   The torchlight swam about the walls with the motion of his arm.

It was then that he noticed the little bald man, standing beside a much taller, also-bald man.  The goblin's brow furrowed, and his little eyes shot back and forth between them.  ""Is that Girrant?"" he piped, peering. ""I thought you would be dead.""  

Yorbi expressed no sentiment of relief regarding the fact that Girrant was, apparently, not.

Tharn nodded his head to the man, who seemed to be trying to compensate for a lack of fur on top, with fur on his chin. He could only hope this Caho was less senseless than his other companions. 

In reply to Yorbi, he said, ""Yorbi, perhaps if there is sorcery closing the door. You could also ... sorcery it open?"" 

'What else are you good for otherwise?' he didn't add. Out loud anyway.

“Dust? Surely we should take our health and leave this place, no?”

Caho sidesteps to allow more room for Girrant to talk sense into his companions.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>“Dust? Surely we should take our health and leave this place, no?”</p><p>Caho sidesteps to allow more room for Girrant to talk sense into his companions.</p>

""Yorbi is searching for a tree,"" Girrant says to Caho, as if by way of explanation. ""It is a tree whose bark has sorcerous properties, which would grant him the powers to, well... do magic, I suppose.""

He is not entirely sure of this explanation himself, but it is the best one he has had from the goblin to date, and it would have to do.

""It would seem that in order to find this tree,"" the dwarf continues, offering the almost-delicious dried scuttleclaw meat around the group. ""We must pass through this... wall... and ultimately, through this ziggurat. If that involves danger and treachery, then so be it - are we not strong, brothers --- and sister?""

It is almost as if he is hesitant about this entire endeavour.
dice roll

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>""Yorbi is searching for a tree,"" Girrant says to Caho, as if by way of explanation. ""It is a tree whose bark has sorcerous properties, which would grant him the powers to, well... do magic, I suppose.""</p><p>He is not entirely sure of this explanation himself, but it is the best one he has had from the goblin to date, and it would have to do.</p><p>""It would seem that in order to find this tree,"" the dwarf continues, offering the almost-delicious dried scuttleclaw meat around the group. ""We must pass through this... wall... and ultimately, through this ziggurat. If that involves danger and treachery, then so be it - are we not strong, brothers --- and sister?""</p><p>It is almost as if he is hesitant about this entire endeavour.</p>

Keeza leaves the de-sorcerizing to the experts and favors Girrant with a fond smile.  He feeds her, after all.

“Girrant, who’s your new friend?”

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Keeza leaves the de-sorcerizing to the experts and favors Girrant with a fond smile.  He feeds her, after all.</p><p>“Girrant, who’s your new friend?”</p>

""Did I not say?"" Girrant says, quizzically. Idly he passes some of the dried dread meat to Keeza. ""Caho Pae. A... monk, of some kind or other. Let us say that he has replaced Sarif, until we find the merchant in---"" he motions to the world in general. ""---this awful place.""

A smile peels across his face. It does not appear to be natural. ""Yorbi may not have the sorcerous power necessary to defeat this stone wall. Might I suggest we continue on our original quest --- that to find the Jhubu Tree of fame --- in order to derive new and mighty wisdom. Then perhaps we can return.""

Now, a grimace. ""And failing to have found new abilities, perhaps we can return with a big c'trulling hammer.""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>""Did I not say?"" Girrant says, quizzically. Idly he passes some of the dried dread meat to Keeza. ""Caho Pae. A... monk, of some kind or other. Let us say that he has replaced Sarif, until we find the merchant in---"" he motions to the world in general. ""---this awful place.""</p><p>A smile peels across his face. It does not appear to be natural. ""Yorbi may not have the sorcerous power necessary to defeat this stone wall. Might I suggest we continue on our original quest --- that to find the Jhubu Tree of fame --- in order to derive new and mighty wisdom. Then perhaps we can return.""</p><p>Now, a grimace. ""And failing to have found new abilities, perhaps we can return with a big c'trulling hammer.""</p>

""A pleasure..."" the monk tones lowly.

As the girl's form comes more into view he quietly lays down his staff at his toes and pulls a vial of amber liquid from his waist pouch. Caho carefully removes the cork and spills a few drops onto his open palm. He circles his hands slowly, warming the liquid and spreading a thin layer of the oil onto both hands.

He reaches for Keeza's hand. ""It is all right child, I can help...""

Stretching further for her he whispers, ""may I?""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>""A pleasure..."" the monk tones lowly.</p><p>As the girl's form comes more into view he quietly lays down his staff at his toes and pulls a vial of amber liquid from his waist pouch. Caho carefully removes the cork and spills a few drops onto his open palm. He circles his hands slowly, warming the liquid and spreading a thin layer of the oil onto both hands.</p><p>He reaches for Keeza's hand. ""It is all right child, I can help...""</p><p>Stretching further for her he whispers, ""may I?""</p>

Keeza shoots Tharn a nervous look.  He’ll back her up, right?  Just in case Caho Pae turns out to be grabby.

She puts out her hand all the same, lifting her chin to hide her misgivings.  “What were you doing in the desert when Girr found you?”

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Keeza shoots Tharn a nervous look.  He’ll back her up, right?  Just in case Caho Pae turns out to be grabby.</p><p>She puts out her hand all the same, lifting her chin to hide her misgivings.  “What were you doing in the desert when Girr found you?”</p>

Caho pins Keeza’s injured hand between his own two soft oiled palms. Bowing his head and kneeling, the monk begins to recite a prayer far too quietly for anyone to hear. A bit of damp warmth seems to emminate from his hands. After what seems like an eternity, the slender man squeezes gently, looks the girl in the eye and begins to stand...

“I’m not entirely sure,” he murmurs as he slowly flicks his eyes, seemingly opening them for the first time that day...“I’ve been wandering for some time... I always seem to be where I should be, if that makes sense.”

Caho finds some dirt and rubs his hands dry and then bends to pick up his staff.

“Your wounds should feel better young one.”

Pae eyes the bear who looms nearby. “Something has brought me to you, so with you I shall stay.”
dice roll

I always seem to be where I should be, if that makes sense.”</p><p>Caho finds some dirt and rubs his hands dry and then bends to pick up his staff.</p><p>“Your wounds should feel better young one.”</p><p>Pae eyes the bear who looms nearby. “Something has brought me to you, so with you I shall stay.”</p>
Tharn Aroa’u, of No Clan nor Cave

Tharn eyes the pair, first giving Keeza a reassuring look that his hammer was at hand if things went too far, and then with slight disbelief as Keeza's wound closes on its own, and skin grew back on itself. 

""Well, I'm glad you're with us. But perhaps it is time we were on our way, if we can't unbend this door for now."" 

He wasn't looking forward to being back in the heat, but being away from this mysterious door, and its promise of death, would be welcome.

column3: [Chapter 1.1] Auerswald and the Road to Steche

column4:
Outside of The Troll's Tongue the town is bustling with activity in the early morning. There's a donkey cart parked beside one of the inn's adjoined buildings and a younger lad offloading crates of produce and other goods off of it inside while the driver idly carves an obscene picture into the plaster wall. Past that the Auersweg leads straight into the heart of the town; the Marktplatz. From every direction someone is yelling something, they hear ""Fresh fish and eels!"" mixing with ""The baths are hot! Tubs and steam! Clean beds!"" and ""Finest arms and armour this side of Altdorf!"" all at once and countless others besides harder to make out from where they're standing. The foot traffic is only now beginning to pick up as they see watchmen opening the town gates, small groups of people coming in from each direction and converging on the market square. Looking down over it all is the statue of Graf Fabian von Wallenstein, the ruling graf's ancestor with his sword held aloft and every detail from his armor to his handlebar mustache meticulously chiseled into the granite, mounted on atop a rearing and wild-eyed warhorse.

To the west lies the Gottesweg, where the vaulted chapel housing the Temple of Sigmar occupies an entire side of the street and the more modest temples to the other gods are forced to share the opposite. To the east lies the Osterweg, lined with the various houses of the tradesmen's guilds with the first floors usually doubling as shops for their memberships' wares. Going north along the upward sloping Weit Strasse leads to the burgerhaus and other government buildings, ending at the gate to the enclosed Hoch Distrikt, where the opulent mansions of the graf and the ruling council of burgomeisters are located. To the southeast the Altweg leads to tenements for the townsfolk with clotheslines criss-crossing between them. In the southwest the Ober Strasse is covered is well-trod cobblestone leading out the western gates and across the flussbrucke on the road to Ubersreik.

Taking the Ober Strasse out of Auerswald and then cutting north along a smaller road running alongside the town wall leads up a hill that is covered in tents and small shacks where various dirt-encrusted women in their threadbare clothes are huddled around campfires or wash basins, while their menfolk are causing a ruckus in various roving groups, some drinking while others surround a pair of bare-chested pugilists. They pay visitors little mind, though occasionally mingling among them are the white robed priestesses of Shallya, praying over convulsing and boil-covered wretches convalescing on bedrolls under a great canvas tarp. Down the other side of the hill the road swings back around and stays only thirty feet away from the banks of the River Teufel. This road, the signpost claims, leads toward Steche.

For all his condescending manners, Coriael keeps his head down and pulls his hair over his pointy ears as best he could. He stuck close to Magnus, more than once the elf had been the target of thrown stones and horse shit, but he doubted any fool here would dare risk hitting the priest.

He walked in silence, ignoring any jibes at his expense.

At the activities of the men gathered drinking and fighting Coriael sighs, such petty and trivial entertainments were ever turning these people from becoming what they potentially could be. For every one human of worth there were half a dozen dull witted idiots.

For every one human of worth there were half a dozen dull witted idiots.</p>

""Dull witted idiots!"" Ziege yells, with skeletal arms spread wide and spittle flying. ""Like rats in a barrel, but by Sigmar's gonads, you don't realize you're rats. You think nothing bad could befall you, even as the world collapses everywhere you look. You think you have purpose -- purpose beyond playthings of the gods, as if they have to listen to you without your pleading.""

He snatches a stick from a nearby vendor, with a gnarled and crispy vermin twisted on it like a pike. ""Here's your future, oh precious and glorious disease-carriers. So please, by all means, carry on filthy vermin. I'm sure the gods are eager to take care of you just because you're so adorable!""

Durchwechsel follows the Witch Hunter out into the street, still puffing on his long stemmed pipe. ""If we're going out into the Wald, I'll be needing to grab a few things."" He proceeds to wander among the market stalls, and spends a double handful of phennig on a couple days worth of groceries, stowing them in his bag. One hand on his rapier, the other on his purse, he'll wander back to the party, keeping his eye open for anything in the stalls which might catch his fancy.

There's several stalls with provisions for travelers, even a regional delicacy of venison and dewberry pemmican wrapped in cheesecloth. As the group wanders toward the guilder's end of the square the selection on display becomes more posh with racks of lange messer, crossbows and even a few items that look of dwarf make.

""I could certainly accompany you there, but not having seen the place myself, and being somewhat less familiar with Auerswald in general, I do not know the way.  Perhaps we can find someone who does?""

The Sigmarite turns to Anders, then looks at Ziege, Snorri, and even Coriael.  ""I don't suppose any of you know where the poor templar was found?  I suspect the priests of Taal might know.""

column2: If you want to just ask around for the information then choose someone to roll a dramatic

Challenging (+0) Gossip test with each person aiding them adding a +10% up to the lead's Fel Bonus. Remember to aid in a test you must also have the skill being rolled. Each attempt represents thirty minutes of chasing down leads as people give you bits of information and then direct you to others who might know more. If you're looking to talk to a specific person and get information from them then you'll be doing an opposed Charm/Cool test with that NPC.

If you want to propose other avenues for discovery or have questions regarding the roll please direct them to the comments of this post.

Finally, a portly washerwoman with a hairy mole prominently featured on her cheek beckons Magnus closer and with breath stinking of onions informs him he should inquire with the High Priest at the Temple of Taal and Rhya along the Gottesweg. She then plants a wet kiss on his cheek and bounds off like a giddy love sick maiden.

She then plants a wet kiss on his cheek and bounds off like a giddy love sick maiden.</p>
“That one of your religious customs in these parts?” Coriael murmurs.

Magnus heads off along the Gottesweg to the Temple of Taal, wiping his cheek furiously with his robes as he does so.
<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Magnus heads off along the Gottesweg to the Temple of Taal, wiping his cheek furiously with his robes as he does so.</p>
Anders follows Magnus. ""No,"" he grumbles to the elf, ""in fact, given the time, I'd confront her disrespect. But there are more important matter to attend to.""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Anders follows Magnus. ""No,"" he grumbles to the elf, ""in fact, given the time, I'd confront her disrespect. But there are more important matter to attend to.""</p>

The moment they start down the Gottesweg they are shaded by the Temple of Sigmar on their right with its tall steeple topped by a bronze icon of Ghal Maraz with a six-pointed halo around its head. Its massive oak doors are opened, revealing the symbols of the twin-tailed comet and the imperial cross painted on the inside of each respectively, the rest of the wood covered in yellowed prayer scrolls secured by purity seals. From inside they can hear faint singing and see flickering candles that light a path toward the altar. But, much as they might be drawn to join the morning devotional, their path forces a sharp leftward turn now and through rows of smaller buildings until they come to an open area of wildflowers and trees surrounding a large wicker hut. The entrance to the hut is lined with sweet smelling herbs woven between the wicker and is topped by a great set of antlers.

Inside the hut five men and women garbed in animal hides and with flowers in their hair are seated in a circle around a dwindling fire, all hurriedly cross-talking in what appears to be an intense discussion. This instantly stops the moment someone notices the group in the doorway. One of the men gets up and approaches them, he wears woolen robes with a deerskin cowl over his head and shoulders. He smells strongly of smoke and honeysuckle and they notice he's missing two fingers on his left hand as he pats his thighs, his chest and then his arms in a quick, practiced movement.

The entrance to the hut is lined with sweet smelling herbs woven between the wicker and is topped by a great set of antlers.</p><hr><p>Inside the hut five men and women garbed in animal hides and with flowers in their hair are seated in a circle around a dwindling fire, all hurriedly cross-talking in what appears to be an intense discussion. He smells strongly of smoke and honeysuckle and they notice he's missing two fingers on his left hand as he pats his thighs, his chest and then his arms in a quick, practiced movement.</p>

He studies his guests for several seconds before he finally speaks in a low and even tone, ""Greetings to you in the Shrine of Taal and Rhya. For what do I owe the presence of Sigmar's favored in this place?""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>He studies his guests for several seconds before he finally speaks in a low and even tone, ""Greetings to you in the Shrine of Taal and Rhya. For what do I owe the presence of Sigmar's favored in this place?""</p>

Magnus bows his head as a sign of respect before looking back into the man's eyes.

""Greetings, Father.  We understand that one of your devotees recently found an untimely end nearby.  I've been sent to learn what transpired, visit the site, and report to my superiors.  We would be most grateful for any insight you may have on what happened, or for directions to where it happened.""

Though not well-trained in the Etiquette of priestly interaction, Magnus tries to remain as polite, formal, and dignified as he can, both to show respect to the Taalites, whose aide he may need, as well as to represent Sigmar well.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Magnus bows his head as a sign of respect before looking back into the man's eyes.</p><p>""Greetings, Father.  We understand that one of your devotees recently found an untimely end nearby.  I've been sent to learn what transpired, visit the site, and report to my superiors.  We would be most grateful for any insight you may have on what happened, or for directions to where it happened.""</p><p>Though not well-trained in the Etiquette of priestly interaction, Magnus tries to remain as polite, formal, and dignified as he can, both to show respect to the Taalites, whose aide he may need, as well as to represent Sigmar well.</p>

The priest's expression remains even, he shows no signs at being disrespected by anything said, and the other Taalites in the hut seem to be taking their cues from him. ""We know only what the Roadwarden informed us; that Brother Warmund was found dead and dismembered at the site of our shrine on the road to Steche."" He looks away momentarily, reaching up and billowing his cowl to let several moths emerge and fly away before continuing, ""-we grieve his loss, but all of us are taught that Taal's realm is perilous. We must continue with our preparations for the celebration of Sonnstill. Once that is complete we will see to the shrine ourselves, until then Brother Warmund is blessed to be able to sustain Taal's children with his sacrifice.""

He walks past the group and into the doorway, pointing out into the distance, ""If you would go there then follow the road north until you come to a forked tree on the right with a carved stone set into the trunk, this marks the beginning of the ancient elf road into the Reikwald. Go no further than fifty paces, you will know the shrine by the standing stones as tall as an Ogre. The shrine stands in the center of this configuration."" He lowers his hand and steps back deeper into the hut. ""I know why your superiors are interested, and I tell you that it is folly. The stories of Black Greta are just that..stories.""

Coriael listens, respectfully for a change. Taalites were....  better. They got it, some of the important things. They were still humans but at least more sensible than the greedy lot that swarmed in cities.

He nodded his understanding of the instructions.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Coriael listens, respectfully for a change. Taalites were....  better. They got it, some of the important things. They were still humans but at least more sensible than the greedy lot that swarmed in cities.</p><p>He nodded his understanding of the instructions. </p>

Ziege was lost back at the Temple of Sigmar. His knees buckled as the group approached the towering cathedral, and while the others marched on, Ziege dragged himself with his arms alone as a man paralyzed from the waste down.

His eyes were kept low, so as not to look upon the gilded hammer or halo, and upon reaching the steps before the open doors, he collapsed and lay perfectly still for several minutes -- taking in the sounds from within but himself relegated beyond the gates, so to speak.

When he finally continues on, he raises his buttocks to the air with forehead still pressed against the stone street; and carefully plods on toward the sanctuary of Taal and Rhya.

----------------------------------

""Black Greta?"" he echoes inquisitively, having missed the conversation leading up to the name. Dirt and blood mingle on his forehead where it has been dragged along the stones, mirrored by the scuffs on his legs below the tattered robes. 

Though clearly intrigued by this name, 'Black Greta', he seems more occupied with looking about him at all the icons and ornamentation of these wilderness gods. A conspicuous grimace of disdain and pity twist is already unsettling features.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Ziege was lost back at the Temple of Sigmar. His knees buckled as the group approached the towering cathedral, and while the others marched on, Ziege dragged himself with his arms alone as a man paralyzed from the waste down.</p><p>His eyes were kept low, so as not to look upon the gilded hammer or halo, and upon reaching the steps before the open doors, he collapsed and lay perfectly still for several minutes -- taking in the sounds from within but himself relegated beyond the gates, so to speak.</p><p>When he finally continues on, he raises his buttocks to the air with forehead still pressed against the stone street; and carefully plods on toward the sanctuary of Taal and Rhya.</p><p>----------------------------------</p><p>""Black Greta?"" he echoes inquisitively, having missed the conversation leading up to the name. Dirt and blood mingle on his forehead where it has been dragged along the stones, mirrored by the scuffs on his legs below the tattered robes. </p><p>Though clearly intrigued by this name, 'Black Greta', he seems more occupied with looking about him at all the icons and ornamentation of these wilderness gods. A conspicuous grimace of disdain and pity twist is already unsettling features.</p>

Magnus considers the name 'Black Greta' for awhile before remembering a snippet from a book entitled The Lives of the Reikland Saints where during The Time of the Three Emperors a Warrior Priest named Henricus von Remer encountered a particularly diabolical witch named 'Black Greta' in the Hagercrybs foothills. It said little about the encounter other than Henricus identified her as a servant of the Ruinous Powers and not the harmless hedgewise the locals thought her to be.

Those familiar with the folklore of the Reikland might know more, if one of you wants to take the lead with the rest helping as you piece together your recollection of the stories surrounding her.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Magnus considers the name 'Black Greta' for awhile before remembering a snippet from a book entitled <em>The Lives of the Reikland Saints </em>where during The Time of the Three Emperors a Warrior Priest named Henricus von Remer encountered a particularly diabolical witch named 'Black Greta' in the Hagercrybs foothills. It said little about the encounter other than Henricus identified her as a servant of the Ruinous Powers and not the harmless hedgewise the locals thought her to be.</p><p>Those familiar with the folklore of the Reikland might know more, if one of you wants to take the lead with the rest helping as you piece together your recollection of the stories surrounding her.</p>

Turning away from the ""temple"" of Taal, Magnus looks towards his newfound companions.  ""The Priests of Taal have been kind enough to point the way.""  Turning to Anders, he speaks in a quieter voice, ""There are rumours circulating of the presence of an ancient Witch who was a servant of the Dark Powers long ago.  I do not expect we shall find her, but it is likely that there is evil afoot.  I trust you are better armed than I.""

His attention still on Anders, Magnus starts towards the northern road, fingering his small dagger with a slight frown.

Coriael scowls, deep in thought. Black Greta....  did that name mean anything?
dice roll
<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Coriael scowls, deep in thought. Black Greta....  did that name mean anything?</p>
The Asrai mage puzzles over the name, but ultimately decides it's just another ridiculous mayfly affectation.
<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>The Asrai mage puzzles over the name, but ultimately decides it's just another ridiculous mayfly affectation.</p>

As if snapped from his quiet disdain by Magnus' whisper of a witch, Ziege flashes a white-eyed stare in the priest's direction -- eyebrows furrowed, as his own memory jogs for more information.

""Black Greta!"" he eventually shouts again... accompanied by the rustling of wildlife disturbed by the outburst. ""I think there was a song about her...""
dice roll

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>As if snapped from his quiet disdain by Magnus' whisper of a witch, Ziege flashes a white-eyed stare in the priest's direction -- eyebrows furrowed, as his own memory jogs for more information.</p><p>""Black Greta!"" he eventually shouts again... accompanied by the rustling of wildlife disturbed by the outburst. ""I think there was a song about her...""</p>

Anders, stoic, nods at Magnus. ""Should any witch appear, then Sigmar will light our way, no doubt."" To himself, however, Anders thinks: I have neither the skill nor weapons to take on a full-blown witch. Truly, I hope Sigmar is with us today.

He ruminates on ""Black Greta,"" however, searching his memory. Have I heard that name before?
dice roll

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Anders, stoic, nods at Magnus. ""Should any witch appear, then Sigmar will light our way, no doubt."" To himself, however, Anders thinks: <em>I have neither the skill nor weapons to take on a full-blown witch. Truly, I hope Sigmar is with us today.</em></p><p>He ruminates on ""Black Greta,"" however, searching his memory. <em>Have I heard that name before?</em></p>

The unkempt fanatic's mind clears long enough to be reminded of a bawdy tavern song about Black Greta, and a few bits of folklore that accompany it, which Anders fleshes out further with accounts he recalls reading in the regional archives of the Order of Sigmar;

""She clutches you tightly with fingers of pitch

Promising pleasures to soothe where ye itch

But know by the Hammer when two are made one

Black Greta takes both heads and leaves thee with none""

According to legend, Black Greta is a witch with black fingers from tip to knuckle who seduces hunters and lone travelers throughout the Reikland. She is said to possess unnatural beauty and youthfulness that she maintains through periodic sacrifice to the Ruinous Powers. The ritual requires her to fashion a cocoon of blood, viscera and skin taken from her sexual partners, with only the skull and phallus left intact (though occasionally one or the other are taken as trophies). Once per decade, she gestates in this cocoon and emerges re-energized. Furthermore, the fruit of her periodic couplings are born as litters of mutants, both human and animal, that serve her whims and defend her during her gestation period.

Over the years many women have been burned for the crime of being 'Black Greta' and yet the stories persist and occasionally signs of her grisly trade emerge as well. A more heretical take on the legend casts her as the spirit of vengeance for women who's lovers abandon them when they become with child, or who are adulterous and carry on relationships with several unknowing women in the different towns they travel. There are even said to be ways to invoke Black Greta and seek her counsel on womanly matters, though the price for her services is steep.

However, the truth of any of this is almost impossible to gauge since all of it comes from tavern gossip, old tales to scare children, and the accounts of unreliable madmen and those extracted by torture.

She is said to possess unnatural beauty and youthfulness that she maintains through periodic sacrifice to the Ruinous Powers. The ritual requires her to fashion a cocoon of blood, viscera and skin taken from her sexual partners, with only the skull and phallus left intact (though occasionally one or the other are taken as trophies). Once per decade, she gestates in this cocoon and emerges re-energized. Furthermore, the fruit of her periodic couplings are born as <i style=""background-color: initial;"">litters </i>of mutants, both human and animal, that serve her whims and defend her during her gestation period.</p><hr>

<p>Over the years many women have been burned for the crime of being 'Black Greta' and yet the stories persist and occasionally signs of her grisly trade emerge as well. A more heretical take on the legend casts her as the spirit of vengeance for women who's lovers abandon them when they become with child, or who are adulterous and carry on relationships with several unknowing women in the different towns they travel. There are even said to be ways to invoke Black Greta and seek her counsel on womanly matters, though the price for her services is steep.</p><p>However, the truth of any of this is almost impossible to gauge since all of it comes from tavern gossip, old tales to scare children, and the accounts of unreliable madmen and those extracted by torture.</p>

Ziege continues to hum the melody of the tune, jumping in occasionally with lyrics as he remembers them, though sporadic and without context.

""It's a good song."" He eventually concedes. ""Catchy for certain, and a great example of where this world is headed. You sing songs like that, then look at me in the morning like I'm the crazy one for trying to fix it. 'Oh yeah, take me head, it's worth it. But by Sigmar's bowels, don't make me wake up for devotions.'""

Now referencing the priest of Taal, but without actually looking at him, he adds, ""He says there's nothing to her, but I doubt it. I tend to be more skeptical of the 'too-good-to-be-true' than the 'too-foul-to-believe'. So count this our warning if we're heading out there, eh?""

column3: (S1, Social) Heat in the Elk Head Bar

column4:
Sitting on the southern end of the main town, a few streets down from the town center. Rests the Elk head bar, one of the oldest bars in town. WHich sports a hunter aesthetic, mounted animal heads, antlers, fish plaques etc. While not the only bar in town it's a popular one for its view of the river and its good selection ofbeers and a decent food.


This evening the locals looking to blow off steam from the searches of the lost children gathered to play pool, watch sports, and enjoy their drinks.  A keen observer can see the melancholy beneath the surface.


Scene Aspects

A gathering of locals

Beer, beer, and some food.

A local establishment with a proud history.


Campaign Issues

Anger and pain over the missing children

Federal agents investigating the town

A Freehold divided


Sitational Aspects:

column1: <div id=""messages-region"" class=""roleplay-messages span_12""><div><div class=""message-list""><div class=""message"" id=""message-327845""><div class=""row"">

Jamie had not come to the bar in quite a while. But she had a hunch she would find The Red Victor here with a few of his redcap posse. SHe pushed open the door and gave a sideways glance to the Deer head mounted on the wall to her left, and the set of antlers decorating the bar.

As she expected the park rangers presence drew some eyes. She knew she was likely going to end up making a scene with Conner. She didn't want to add alcohol into the mix.  The she stag-moved up to the bar and ordered in a clear and audible voice.

“Arnold Palmer, thanks Chuck”

Taking the drink she looked over to the pool tables, spying the gathering of Redcaps. She felt the blood drum inside of her head.

Here goes nothing….

Jamie moves over towards the group and cleared her throat. Resting her hand on her hip. She didn't have much sway in the freehold, but she had some athourity in town...some.

“Conner”

column2: At the sound of Jamie clearing her throat, and the mention of his name, Conner didn't look up. Instead he leaned over the pool table, cue in hand, lining up his shot. Arrayed about their corner of the Elk Head, the Redcaps turned to look at the Ranger. Emmet Aspen, a Darkling Tunnelgrub stood near the Red Victor, and drummed pallid fingers on the pool stick he held in front of him. Russel Hogan, an Ogre Gristlegrinder with the mask of a stocky middle aged man, faced the Runnerswift squarely. Miranda Klose, an Elemental Ask-wee-da-eed seated on a stool near the Ogre, frowned.

Conner smiled, finished the stroke, and straightened. He gestured with his chin at the empty pint beside the Ogre, silently indicating it's emptiness. At this, Russel grunted and plucked up his glass. He nudged Mira and tilted his head towards the bar. The Elemental blinked, glanced at Conner, and deepened her frown to a scowl directed at Jamie, but took her glass and departed as well. Emmet, expressionless, set his cue against the wall and drifted after them.
Conner touched the brim of his hunting hat with a finger in greeting and spoke.

column1:
Jamie watched as the two gangers moved towards the bar. She gives them a curt nod before her eyes swiveled towards Conner...and his hat.

The she-stag paused, she had moved into this situation more unprepared than she had anticipated and now was face to face with The Redcap...the Red victor. She bit the inside of her lip, the sharp pain dilated her eyes and pulled her focus in again.

Her heart pounded.

“Hope your having a good game. “ she said idly as she grasped out for her words.

“ I am not going to beat around the bush Conner”
The summer courtiers attention hesitated for a moment as she glanced to the gathering of mortals in the bar. Most knew better not to pay attention to the Red caps. The others who were drawn to the possibility of town drama were too far away for Jamie to worry about secrets.


“What happened at the Moot. We need to talk about  it”

column2: Again he said nothing and watched the Runnerswift closely. She stood posed to project calm confidence. With one hand on her hip and a drink in the other, Jamie had squared her shoulders and prepared for a confrontation. It was as much a mask as the glamour that hid her antlers. She was studiously not stiff, but that wasn't the same as relaxed. Conner noticed when her eyes dilated, watched her small dark nose flare when she steadied herself for the conflict with a breath. Then she slipped up.

She turned to look at the bar, baring her throat. With her head angled back, the slender muscles in her neck stood out sharply, pressing against skin, pushing veins closer to the surface. The Hunterheart could see her pulse. Hart. A quick glance showed her unprotected belly. Her efforts to seem relaxed put her arms splayed to the sides leaving her vulnerable. Her toned legs boasted her kith's appellation, Hind, but she'd stepped too close. At this distance he-

She turned back to him, and he managed to keep from baring his teeth. He had more or less come to terms with his altered nature, and normally he felt more in control, but it was worse with Jamie. He forced his thoughts to order. Her glance back had been to the bar, either making sure his people had moved off, or checking to see that the mortal patrons of the pub were out of earshot in compliance with Freehold policy. It was that one. It was Jamie after all. He was pretty sure they wouldn't be overheard. Most folks in Naukati gave him his space.
The Moot. He'd figured that was what brought her here. He was intrigued enough that he'd sent away the others to give her the floor, time to hear her out.

column1:
The words of the Redvictor landed on her like a shove.  Causing her again to question her motives in coming here.  It was obvious that corner was not appreciating her interruption, then again why would he. She was just a man- at arms after all. 

“Look Conner. These are...challenging times and uh “ she hesitated. Took a deep breath.

Say your peace damn it

“Your actions at the gathering. Were...you made us look bad. We might not agree on everything...or anything. But we can't look weak like that. Not right now”

She fidgeted. She wanted to also say that by her standing up and taking his side at the moot, meant a target was painted on her by the Magister of nightmares. She doesn't have Conners titles or his gang to protect her.

“It was selfish of you to put us in that spot” 

Why did you come here, you idiot?  Jamie felt a desperate desire to be home right at this moment.

column2: Conner set the butt of the pool cue against the worn timber floor of the Elk Head Bar and leaned the stick against the table while Jamie built up to her point. She looked as though she might paw at the ground with her boots any second. He wondered if her feet were cloven. Then she described the current crisis.

Conner suppressed the annoyance that rose up in him. More diplomatic bullshit. He could just hear the Sunbanisher or the Magister of Nightmares calling missing children challenging times. He was at the pub that night to get Mira out of the house, away from tending her decompensating father, away from the terror that her brother had been either abducted or died and the nauseating prospect of which fate was worse. Despite that, it was his actions at the Moot that were the source Jamie's grievance. She worried his priorities had made the Summer court look bad, look weak. That he was selfish. No shit they didn't agree.

The Redcap was warm against his scalp. He considered the fidgeting Man-at-Arms. She hadn't meant to belittle the situation. She was concerned with how the Iron Spear presented itself before the assembled Freehold and from her perspective he had made the herd seem disorganized. She hadn't thought it through. The Court of Wrath was already weak, biddable and gelded.

The Victor reached down and fished a few of the pool balls up from the slide on the side of the table. They hadn't played a full game before Jamie showed up, and the few they had put down the pockets had fed through the mechanism. He ferried them back on to the felt with a clawed hand a few at a time. Conner shook his head.
He set the triangle on the table, but before she had to ask him on which point he disagreed, he continued.
""It wasn't selfish. Being agreeable doesn't mean being respected."" Conner returned his gaze to the ranger. ""What's the purpose of the Summer Court?""
